The Kingmaker is the story of ruthless and narcissistic Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, and her family’s attempts to work their way back into power after her husband’s overthrow.Imelda was the wife of the corrupt Ferdinand Marcos, who ruled the country between 1965-1986. In interviews she comes across as caring, generous, and eccentric, but the documentary reveals the more sinister aspects of her and her husband's rule; in particular the theft of billions from the country and a period of brutal dictatorship involving torture, rape and murder.During martial law in the Philippines over 3,000 people were killed and 70,000 imprisoned, some for as little as being at a meeting with five or more people. Activists appear in the film with chilling stories of being tortured and sexually assaulted under the Marcos regime. The reign of terror lasted until Ferdinand was overthrown after trying to rig an election in 1986, ushering in democracy in the country over the protests of some of America’s Cold War hawks.It’s never clear how involved Imelda was in the worst acts of her husband’s government, although there are hints in the film that she helped to mastermind the assassination of an opposition leader. It is obvious that she benefitted from the record-breaking corruption of the Marcos regime; as a result her habit of handing out wads of money to the poor takes on a sinister air.If there is one word to sum up Imelda, it is narcissistic. Throughout the documentary her hunger for popularity goes beyond all reason; she sees nothing wrong with importing giraffes and zebras into a country where there are no vets to take care of them, leaving them suffering from skin diseases. At one point, she seemingly sincerely says that Chairman Mao told her that she could end the Cold War.Her accumulation of wealth goes beyond practical levels and seems compulsive; her family looted a literally record-breaking amount of money and helped to impoverish The Philippines for decades, and on a more petty level she was famous for having a collection of over 3,000 shoes. You could say that Imelda is similar to Trump, or alternatively, that Trump resembles any number of self-deluded dictators throughout history, who tend to be self-obsessed in the worst way.Such characters have an enduring appeal despite their ridiculousness, and as many people in the documentary note, the Philippines has been forgiving to strongmen in the past. With Rodrigo Duterte's brutal rule coming to an end and Imelda's son Bongbong Marcos in power in the Philippines as of May 2022, the country may unfortunately be on a path to repeating its previous mistakes.

“i don’t have an answer for why we allow imelda to even open her mouth.” i don’t think any of my followers here are filipino, but i hope non-filos especially could take some time to read this review.the kingmaker follows imelda marcos, the wife of a former dictator of the philippines. ferdinand marcos had declared martial law over the philippines, causing years of terror and corruption and pain for the vast majority of filipinos. in this documentary, imelda marcos discusses her problems during her time as first lady… victimizing her family despite the power they held (still hold) and the money they stole from the country. this documentary does a great job in portraying the vastness of their family’s wealth, going as far as to show imelda’s house full of legal cases against the family. they are the antithesis of freedom and truth. this documentary was filmed during the 2016 presidential election wherein imelda’s son, ferdinant marcos jr., ran for vice presidency and eventually lost. in 2022, he has somehow taken the lead for presidency despite what his family has done. the youth of the country are afraid of what he’ll do. the youth are disappointed that the work done by the activists— who fought fiercely for their freedom during the martial law era— will possibly have their work be undone. with the family’s reputation for historical revisionism, the people are afraid that the truth and the torture endured by activists of that time will be forgotten. i encourage everyone to give this documentary a shot. it’s well made and very relevant to the philippines today. “i will not have my president be named Ferdinand Marcos… AGAIN!”

"Perception is real, the truth is not." Lauren Greenfield's elegantly crafted doc about the political dynasty in the Philippines. Another maddening look at how those with wealth and power will never give it up, coming up with new ways to maintain their dominant command of power. One of these films that just makes me so angry about how much wealth rules the world and how they manipulate the masses so much (to be in their favor). And keep getting away with it. I like the way this doc is put together, it has a more compelling narrative than her last film Generation Wealth, but is just as fascinating to watch.

Lauren Greenfield, in her new documentary, focuses on the former Filipino first lady Imelda Marcos, who despite everything she has witnessed (made up of abuse, murder, embezzlement) still remains in her nation's political scene. An essential, no-frills documentary that portrays the political history of the Philippines and the dictatorial regime of the Marcos through a key and a maternal look represented by this matron with strongly materialistic excesses (her shoes collection for example).
A very well crafted documentary. Even when I was losing interest, Lauren Greenfield found a way to bring me back in.

I found this movie more interesting as a character study of a divisive and admittedly fascinating woman than a cliff notes version of the political history of the Philippines. I also thought it was over-edited at times, as if the audience wouldn’t be trusted to come to a specific conclusion without just the right soundbite to punctuate a moment or scene. It got to be a lot. Messy, complicated, compelling doc about a genuinely thorny subject.

Sets off as an Imelda Marcos profile with a wicked sense of humour, and slowly morphs into a disturbing exposé of the inbreeding of a political dynasty poised for a comeback (more accurately, the point is that they never really went away). The film is largely about image maintenance, and it’s fascinating to see Marcos so obviously convinced that this film is just another propaganda vehicle. It’s maybe a little too sprawling too quickly, and the story remains ominously unfinished, but I admired the film’s ambition and clarity. “Perception is real, and the truth is not” says Marcos. The film’s relevance extends far beyond the Philippines.

"Perception is real, and the truth is not". These terrifying words come from the delusional Imelda Marcos, whose influence on politics in the Philippines is scary. The Kingmaker interviews Marcos at length, only for it to become clear that she is a greedy liar seeking to play the victim. Her opulent lifestyle and desire to birth a paradise is slowly realised to come from a scary place. As The Kingmaker is mostly a conventional documentary, aside from its lack of chronology, it feels likely to become a neoliberal piece of mild condemnation without the guts to pick apart Filipino politics. Yet The Kingmaker does find a voice, and manages to find fault in the more liberal governments in the Philippines. Their inability to solve the problems are shown by the film's eventual focus on the resurgence of the Marcos family and their proxy candidate, the evil Rodrigo Duterte. It is a sad and scary time for the Philippines and really this story is still breaking. Who knows if The Kingmaker is telling this slice of history at its beginning or end.There's horrifying moments in The Kingmaker, such as the chilling accounts of torture, the children who openly like martial law, and the fact that Rodrigo Duterte has any power. As a documentary this may not be very inspired, but the subject matter is vital for us all to know. The inbreeding nature of politics has allowed one family to have influence, either overtly or covertly, over an entire country for decades. Perhaps Imelda Marcos does have a plan for paradise, but is the path to it justifiable?2019 Ranked

A real disappointment. Where The Queen of Versailles provided a real examination of its subjects, set against the backdrop of the financial crisis, this film throws its hands up at meaningful probing and morphs into a filmed Wikipedia article. It's pleasant enough to watch, but the people who applauded and harrumphed in solidarity with the final text captions could have just read an article on the 2016 Philippine election to get the same reaction.

*followed by a Q&A featuring Director Lauren Greenfield*Imelda Marcos isn’t someone I was familiar with at all prior to this documentary but it didn’t take much to see how she is a prime candidate for a film. Her personality is eye catching and confusing while also being headstrong and assertive. The Q&A that took place following the screening helped improved my view of the film as some of the director’s choices made more scene after hearing how they came to be. One issue I had/have is the level of focus early on on Imelda’s bring of animals to an island and running off its prior inhabitants. While this is an interesting and quirky story, it is later followed up with the film’s first deep dive into the era of Marshall Law in the Philippines brought on by her late husband Ferdinand Marcos. This is far more interesting and far more important to the narrative than this island full of giraffes and I had issues with the time allotment of the two, as well as how much of the earlier portion of the doc feels far too casual given the level of information that is conveyed in the later half. While still is problematic for me, it helped to hear that over the process of filming this movie, much of the later events weren’t even in play yet. So at the time the film felt like it was going to be one thing before new storylines emerged. It doesn’t completely remove my issues about it but it make more sense and for me makes it more understandable a choice. It is a documentary worthy of keeping an eye out for as I think much of it will be a welcomed source of information for most about the political issues in the Philippines and how people like Imelda can be so influential to even if from a distance she looks like a comical character of sorts.

To a person who only knows the history of the Marcos dynasty from the Wikipedia article this was appropriately terrifying and illuminating. There are some major issues with the film itself; I can't be sure but it feels like Laura Greenfield went in expecting to just do a bio/exposé on Imelda but then got ensnared in the insanity of 2016 national election. The movie struggles with mission creep; the last 30 minutes depicting the results of that surprising election unfold at breakneck speeds that barely hang together and then at the end require a long series of title cards. It feels tacked-on but I'm not sure that there was any other way to convey the insane turn the story was taking.

The explosive story of Imelda Marcos, and her rise from being Miss Manila in Phillipines to becoming the First Lady there. Inspite of years or corruption, political manipulation, murders, and even after being sent to exile out of the country; She still managed to come back, and remains relevant because of her political tact and emotional manipulation of the people of Phillipines.

Lauren Greenfield ("The Queen of Versailles," "Generation Wealth") has once again proven why she's my favorite documentary filmmaker, and one of my favorite filmmakers, period. She explores new territory in "The Kingmaker," without straying away from her signature "photographic" and intimate style; the DNA of her style is felt and serves as a backbone to new elements that elevate it to another level in order to successfully cover the story of Imelda Marcos and politics in The Philippines. Everything I admire about her body of work is present on this one: Metaphors of excess and unbalance and its consequences; glamour and its beauty, but also how comical it can be; the obsession with material things and its demons. However, due to the nature of the subject, it goes a step further, diving into political territory and giving us a cautionary tale about power and greed that is harsh, timely, but hopeful. This project might not have been the culmination of 25 years of work like "Generation Wealth," but it's probably the most challenging one Greenfield has had to make. The challenges of this five-year endeavor are seen and felt on the screen, but they pay off. If Greenfield and her team were able to accomplish this, then I cannot wait to see what's next in store.I highly recommend this documentary: A portrait of a woman in and out of power; of a country in and out of justice; of a political system in and out of the past. If you're in LA or New York, make sure you catch it in theaters starting November 8th.
this loses focus like two thirds of the way through? but I think is still a good documentary for the most part?

Low 3.Got to go to a special screening followed by a conversation with Director Lauren Greenfield. I sadly have not seen any of her previous work. I also had no idea what this was about. I seriously hate movies like this because it reminds me just how little I know of the world.  I knew nothing about Marcos. Don't know anything about the Philippines even. As I've said before Documentaries aren't my go to genre but I will always be grateful they exist because I love learning about things I never knew about. Pretty crazy all the stuff that was shown here.But I found this to be pretty confusing. I wasn't sure how I was supposed to feel for Imelda Marcos at first. I just mean the way the story was laid out. The audience reaction to certain things was different to mine as well which added to my confusion. Then for me I'm not even sure how people in the Philippines feel about Imelda Marcos? At one point it seems like everyone hates her but then it seems like people now love her? I guess I would have like interviews from people explaining why they love her. I guess it's just something I'll have to look into myself. I don't know for me I just didn't really like the way this was laid out. It painted her as a great lady then out of no where we were supposed to hate this family then they would explain why. I think I would have liked a more linear storyline. BUT during the conversation she did actually speak to that. She said when doing a documentary the audience believes what they are seeing. So what do you do when you have a subject that lies? So I guess that explains the storyline feeling all over the place for me because she would cut to actual facts after Imelda Marcos said something that wasn't true. So that does make sense but it just really had a way of feeling disjointed for me. Also there was a part where they were interviewing someone about something really dark and personal and before they finished talking cut to another interview about the same topic and that really threw me. So it was two people talking about something similar at the same time. I didn't like that I would have preferred to hear one at a time especially about something so sad. But yeah I guess I would have just liked things better explained. I feel as someone who knows nothing about what went down I would have liked to know more about when Martial Law happened and about how they were accused of stealing millions. I just feel like things weren't explained as good as I would have liked. Felt like it just touched the surface. This would focus on different things all at once and like I said just felt all over the place for me. But it was still good and learned a lot. Pretty shocking all that happened and what all is still going on. And seriously Animal Island broke my heart. I'd say check this out if you can, I believe it will be on Showtime. You may enjoy this more than I did and if anything the interviews and the access Greenfield had to Imelda Marcos is very impressive.

While Lauren Greenfield’s previous films (Queen of Versailles, Generation Wealth) have been political, her newest, The Kingmaker, is her first to be overtly about politics. But her pet themes are still on display. The site of Imelda Marcos mobbed by children and adults as she hands out cash or of Ferdinand Marcos’ body, still lying in state and preserved under glass nearly 30 years after his death, are just the newest exhibits in Greenfield’s cinematic museum highlighting grotesque displays of wealth...Read the full review at Battleship Pretension:battleshippretension.com/the-kingmaker-feet-on-the-ground-by-david-bax/

A worthy introduction to the madness that is Philippine politics. It's a crash course on the Marcoses and one of the darkest eras in the Philippines. While its attempt at weaving the incumbent leadership with the Marcos dynasty can at times be a stretch, as a Filipino, I can see how this might be the image that non-Filipinos have of the Philippines.As with most films and rooms that she inhabits, Imelda Marcos is magnetic. She's a modern-day Rasputin, who can hypnotize people and place them under her spell. Perhaps it is not the filmmaker's intention that when we do not hear from Imelda for a stretch of time, the movie slows down to a halt.In those long stretches, we yearn for more Imelda on screen. Like the Philippines, we are smitten from the first minute to the last. And suddenly, even with all the horrors that they are responsible for, we realize why the Marcoses keep coming back and back to haunt Filipinos until our dying days.

One of the ways you can tell how good Lauren Greenfield is at this sort of picture is that she's able to highlight how magnetic and seductive a subject like Imelda Marcos is while laying the groundwork for how tremendously destructive she can be. Imelda Marcos is many things: the former first lady of the Philippines, a popular figure in that country, someone who loves fashion, a collector of fine art, and a devoted family person. She imagines herself to be many other things: Chief among them is her self-professed role as the "mother of the Philippines." The truth, of course, has little to do with such hollow or imagined descriptions, and The Kingmaker, a documentary portrait of Marcos that only becomes more terrifying as it progresses, cuts to the core of what happens when one person's ego becomes more important than the welfare of a country.See my full review at Mark Reviews Movies.

Lauren Greenfield often interviews beauty queens and those whose lives are distorted by their wealth. Take Greenfield's previous themes and add politics to this documentary which covers Imelda Marcos, the wife of Filipino dictator Ferdinand Marcos. "Meldy" melts our hearts by telling us how she was friends with Mao, Castro, Gaddafi, Hussein, and how Richard Nixon was just misunderstood. Breaking the backs of the Filipino people, she amassed 3,000 pairs of shoes in addition to expensive dresses and a bulletproof bra (the pricetag of the final dress she ordered was revealed to be $80,000).Toward the end of the film, Imelda begs us for sympathy, detailing how hard it was to lose everything (that she had gained illegally). Tough luck, girl.Vegan alert: -Shipping animals from Africa-Animals were shot when the locals felt they were destroying their livelihood-Due to the lack of care for the animals, inbreeding occurred and the giraffes have shorter necksWomen were also interviewed detailing how they were sexually abused during the regime.

"The Kingmaker" begins as an unfettered check-in on the life of one of the 20th century's most notorious figures, Imelda Marcos. Like a visit to the zoo, we're granted the opportunity to observe the seemingly self-delusional Marcos in her current habitat as she dreams of a time and place she no longer occupies. Filmmaker Lauren Greenfield allows Imelda the chance to justify, in her own words, her and her late husband's ruthless and corrupt reign as the authoritarian overlords of the Philippines. Greenfield doesn't assist Imelda in her efforts to rewrite history, but she allows Imelda to state her case even as the film mixes in interviews from former friends and enemies (and victims). There are even moments of humor during the film's early-going, as Imelda's obliviousness to the audience's feeling of disgust toward her wastefully lavish and cartoonish lifestyle, cruel indifference for the rights of her fellow countrymen, and insistence on innocence lands perfectly as a joke at the former Filipino First Lady's expense.However, the film transforms into something far uglier and more frightening as Greenfield transitions from mere case study to political exposé (albeit, one that could be a bit more focused). Like watching a horror film, "The Kingmaker" turns the joke around on the Filipino people and the audience. Laugh as you might at Imelda and her seemingly fantastical defenses of the Marcos regime and her pipe dream of seeing her son, BongBong, someday elevated to the presidency, the terrifying and telling reality is that Imelda has not yet been relegated to 20th century has-been. At nearly 90, she's a member of the Filipino House of Representatives, the mother of an influential Filipino senator (her daughter) and a very possible future president (her son), and a behind-the-scenes benefactor of the current authoritarian-leaning president, Rodrigo Dutarte. Delusional though she may be, Imelda is still as cunningly manipulative as ever. Hell, she may be once again controlling the strings of power in the Philippines, more than 30 years after she and her husband were forced into exile. It's the kind of film that sends a chill down your back as the credits roll.

~AFI FEST 2019~Ferdinand, Imelda's husband (the kingmaker) was president of the Philippines from 1965-1989 and rumors had spread that the couple had used their power to assassinate politician Benigno Acquino which was a major factor in the way the public begun to view the pair. It was a case filled with fraud and speculation on how this couple was making their money yet a lack of solid evidence to support that whatever it was they were doing was unjust. Today, the concern is that Imelda's son, Bongbong is on his way to ruling the Philippines which terrifies many since history is seemingly beginning to repeat itself in the sense that whoever speaks out negatively about the family suddenly disappears or is subject to assassination with a cover up. I just find this so insane and I feel the best thing to do is to spread the word. It's such a controversial case and Lauren Greenfield did an excellent job at showing both perspectives. I don't want to spoil anything so i'm just going to leave this at a strongly recommend & if anyone's watched this and would like to discuss it I'd be open to sharing some thoughts!

Hard for me to be objective about this as I’m married to a Filipino whose mother is from the same province as Imelda and is supportive of her for what appears to me to be purely tribal reasons. With that aside as much as I can put it, I think it’s a well done doc that tells a story of interest to those unfamiliar with the Philippines but with some amount of curiosity about other cultures. More than once my husband said aloud “I didn’t know that” in-between laughs at Mrs. Marcos’ lack of self awareness. Those who never venture far from home and shake their heads in judgement when told of cultures different from from theirs could find it tedious, but it’s done well enough that anyone willing to give it the short 100 minutes will come away educated and entertained.

Beneath the thick make-up and perfected smile of Imelda Marcos there seems to be something more sinister and unnerving about her appearance. “Perception is real and truth is not,” she says when speaking about accusations of torture and abuse of power, and it's this understanding of how to manipulate her image that has enabled her to remain outside of a prison cell for so long. It’s a warped form of cognitive dissonance that director Lauren Greenfield has captured in her documentary, The Kingmaker, showing the rise, fall and steady rise again of the Marcos clan in the Philippines.Greenfield has spent much of her career documenting the rich and deluded, which made Marcos the perfect subject. She is famous for her lavish lifestyle which included the ownership of thousands of luxury brand shoes and the spending over $2 billion of state money during her time in power. But the longer Greenfield spent with Imelda, the more obvious it became she was an unreliable narrator, locked away in a fantasy bubble refusing to face up to the pain her family has caused the Philippine people for the past half century.Imelda dominates the first half of the film speaking about her journey to government alongside former husband, and now deceased President, Ferdinand Marcos. At the same time she is galvanising support behind her son, Bongbong, while he seeks election as Vice President. Greenfield managed to secure good access to the former First Lady with a one-on-one interview at home, also following her as she travels through the Manila slums (“it never used to be like this” she says with faux incredulity) handing out cash from the huge wad fixed to her side. She makes a good fist of playing the ‘woman of the people’ role, but it is little more than a sham.Review continues over at The Digital Fix

Classic Greenfield. Imelda Marcos is given free rein to exhibit her own folly and delusion, while interspersed archival footage and other interviews show the true story of the Marcos regime in the Philippines. While generally a troubling and depressing story, The Kingmaker has its lighter moments and dark comedy, a tonal mix that Greenfield manages beautifully. The ending hints at the possibility that Rodrigo Duterte's election as president may have been part of some larger plot to return a scion of the Marcos family to power. While interesting, I'm not sure this theory is fleshed out enough to merit inclusion.

Lauren Greenfield has made films about people with immense wealth before, and both those and her books tend to cover that uncomfortable collision of aspirational wealth and real lived experiences, about little corners of the human psyche (or rather bigger ones in some cases) that desire the glossy fashion spread lifestyle. Imelda Marcos largely fits neatly into that, but with a far bigger and more dangerous political footprint that continues to make itself felt. Ostensibly the title is about her relationship with her husband, the massively corrupt dictator of the Philippines for two decades from the mid-60s to the mid-80s (at which point he was ousted by a 'People Power' revolution via the wife of an assassinated opposition leader, Corazon Aquino), whose power she was said to manipulate for her own ends, most famously for the acquisition of art, designer items and of course shoes. But the film moves quickly on from these trappings to her real and lingering effect on Filipino politics, via her family's dynasty and their support for current dictator-wannabe Rodrigo Duterte. Stylistically it frames Marcos with the opulence of her living spaces, repeatedly showing her handing out money to her loyal supporters crowding around her car or in public appearances (often held and distributed by her staff). She shows off art and photos of her with world leaders (at one point hilariously, but utterly unconcernedly, breaking some of these framed highlights while reaching to show off one, I think with her and Nixon). She is also apparently blithely unaware of how her namedropping comes across, especially when she's talking about aforementioned world leaders or her art collection. She could be a figure of fun, but gradually the film becomes more and more serious about her impact, as it layers on the Marcos's crimes and the real effects of the policies and division they have sowed within the society, paving the way for her and her family's chilling return to power.

The worst kind of villains are the villains who believe that they are doing the right thing. It is clear from this brutally honest documentary that she truly believed she was incapable of doing no wrong. To quote the film "Hustlets" from this earlier this year, "motherhood is a mental illness" and Imelda and the whole Marcos family are the cause of the various illnesses that run plague in my home country. Being a Filipino who lives abroad is a blessing as I am away from the violence and disasters back home, but a curse because I cannot be more than an observer. I can only do my part to try and fight the cynical thoughts in my head saying "we have always been corrupt" "there is nothing we can do", "that is just how things are done". I've been apathetic to injustice due to my privilege. I am grateful for the life I have and what has been provided for me but it is that privilege that has made me not care. The Kingmaker has awakened a deep anger inside me regarding what has been done to my country. I emplore all Filipinos who have access to it, to see it. Even if you disagree with it. I guarantee all Filipinos can take something from watching it. I can only hope that the Marcos' never return to Malacañang. Ever.

I'm pleased to report that this is a far superior and less odiously self-indulgent that Greenfield's Generation Wealth. The Kingmaker starts from a position of curiosity and sympathy (there's something of The Fog of War in Jocelyn Pook's Philip Glassy score); Imelda Marcos as ridiculous but tragic, and maybe misunderstood. The second half of the film morphs into Act of Killing territory and the testimony of victims of the Marcos dictatorship cause the mask to slip. Her attempts to propel her David Brent-like son to power likewise move from mildly pathetic to deeply troubling. Ultimately a film that speaks to a variety of worrying political trends across the world, and how perception trumps truth at all turns.

Really brilliantly constructed - the film sets up as a cosy, cute, harmless portrait of an eccentric celebrity in her grey years, and allows itself to remain in that framework as the body count grows higher, as Kissinger dances on the screen, as the talking heads, initially brought in to provide sappy reminiscing about Imelda's public life, begin to admit propping up dictators for the US' foreign policy interests or detail their sexual assault at the hands of the Marcos regime, as the gormless Jeb Bush-like son goes from affable mummy's boy to a brutal example of the violence of capital exerting itself, and of course as it ends with the still-unfolding nightmare of Duterte. The usefulness of this for the film is that it provides an aesthetic critique of the influence of capital on society by relating everything back to Marcos, in that we see that all its awful violence, its total control over humanity, its manufacturing of poverty and suffering, don't serve some sort of greater noble cause, but instead simply exist so that an elite can buy shoes and completely bizarre confirmations of their self-image. It's useful sometimes to remember how utterly ugly it all is, and how power has no correlation to either intelligence or beauty, it just exerts itself in service of itself - I'd never immediately disbelieve someone who told me the rich devote their whole lives to worshipping Molloch and doing satanic rituals, because there's no need for these things to be real for the idiotic rich to exploit the world in practicing them, as Marcos' obsessive world-mother fantasy and surreal safari island show. The woozy, nightmarish quality of the film's descent into horror doesn't distract from the reality, and it's a serious documentary that isn't reductive to just pointing at the absurdity of the rich. Instead, it uses these contrasts to make the total dominion of capital in public life and its attendant brutality that protects and asserts the power of the dominant elite all the more vivid, and shows how apparently laughable figures like Duterte can exist as the sinew between capitalism and fascism, artificially creating a need and then fulfilling it with a solution that has no alternative (or, a failed neoliberal alternative), like Marcos literally buying the affection of the poor she helped impoverish. It's that clear critique of capital as a structure and empathy for the oppressed throughout that keeps it from being just liberal aesthetic critique, although mockery of the venal rich still has its place - don't let unfunny US talk show hosts take it away from you completely.

Likable enough and entertaining but lacks the unique personal style of Greenfield's previous work.In a way, Marcos is the ultimate Greenfield subject and you kinda wish, it wasn't so focused with a yeoman-like investigation on present-day Filipino political corruption and human-rights crimes.Sure, Marcos is a focal-point in Filipino politics but we spend a lot of time away from Imelda, to focus on the other stuff.

Greenfield tells this story with almost a degree of flippancy at the beginning as the audience is invited to laugh at Imelda Marcos and her inflated ego and mock her for her crocodile tears for the victimhood she claims. Then we are shaken out of this feeling with reminders of the reality of the Marcos regime - Aquino's assassination most of all.We are then left with the image of a figurehead with an evil murderous past, left powerless and benign in her advancing years - her campaign to have her eldest son elected Vice President fails.But Greenfield hasn't done pulling the rug from under the audience's feet with a final horrible sting in the tail that really explains the film's title. It turns out this is no laughing matter after all - the bad guys are winning again.

As with many documentaries we play at E Street, I had no idea who the Marcos family were. It's directed by the same director of The Queen of Versailles and Generation Wealth and although I have been meaning to catch up on those, this fits perfectly in a trilogy about wealth and class. It's really well put together and informative for those like me who don't know about this and the current state of the Philippians politics and how this type of dynasty is being rooted into our politics today with Jr. having aspirations to run for Mayor or Governor of New York. It's a really fantastic documentary and among the best of the year!Also my 100th Landmark E Street New Release of 2019! Only 2 left for my year challenge!

Sly documentary follows an elderly Imelda Marcos as she works to install her feckless son with Ferdinand Marcos, Bongbong, as vice-president of the Philippines. Imelda likes to lie just about as much as Donald Trump, and she likes power just about as much too. This is the story of how Marcos money has thoroughly corrupted the Philippines. It's about the con job the Marcos clan pulled and continue to pull on the people of the Philippines--they even convinced some proles that seven years of martial law were the good old days when the country thrived. Director Greenfield just stays quietly out of the way and lets the facts and Imelda prosecute their own case. One interesting line of thought suggests that the country's current murderous dictator, Rodrigo Duterte, is a Marcos stooge installed to grease Bongbong's path, & who will step aside when it's time for Bongbong to take power. It's all jaw-dropping, and provides a convenient road-map to how dictators establish authoritarian rule. We should be paying close attention.
the story of Imelda Marcos is bigger than the doc.

Portrait of a delusional yet absolutely terrifying persona, a comic-book villain under whose absurdity lies the sinister potential to realise these delusions through the self-justifying mythos of a national narrative. Wish this explored the tumultuous years under Marcos’ martial law at a deeper socio-economic level, and also the country’s political landscape during and post Marcos; make no mistake, the real star of the show is Imelda, a seemingly impossible amalgamation of naïveté and shrewdness, delusion and self-awareness.

Portrait of Imelda Marcos, the should-be disgraced ex first lady of the Philippines, as she plots a comeback for the Marcos family by sponsoring her son Bongbong's vice presidential campaign. Extremely depressing reminder that democracy and dictatorship are not incompatible.
I knew nothing about this subject matter going in other than a vague “Philippines human rights abuse” idea, and I kinda had my shit rocked. Interesting stuff!

Do we feel something when we see Imelda Marcos being pushed around in a wheelchair, or when her memory seems to fail her, or when she betrays some delusion about her place in history? Yes, because we have empathy; unlike some of those currently occupying high office, we're not complete sociopaths. Yet the movie leaves us in little doubt that these most performative signs of weakness - as with any suggestion that Imelda might be considered a victim - may in themselves be a show, a form of spin, and that they are as nothing when one sets them against the lifetime of pain and suffering endured by the Filipino poor. Greenfield induces that wary, guarded empathy one might feel in close proximity to a wounded lion or wolf, creatures that, though laid low, may just rally long enough overnight to make a second lunge for your throat or chest. Even if they can't eat you, their more vigorous offspring still might.

Fascinating subject matter keeps the film engaging and there is an admirable wealth of materials put together. Definitely an interesting watch if you know little about Filipino politics. But it is not a very solid film because it attempts to do three things at once. It starts as a portrait of Imelda Marcos, turns into a broader study of recent Filipino history, then becomes a film about the 2016 vice presidential election. Each could be a great film on its own, but that’s too much for just 100 minutes. It is interesting, but somewhat superficial for this reason. Reading Imelda Marcos’ Wikipedia page or just checking who won the election (if you don’t already know) could cover most of the same ground. This is decent as a primer, but I now want to read/watch much more about Imelda Marcos.

Furstrating in parts but important nevertheless.The documentary makes some unfortunate choices. Noynoy Aquino quotes Santayana about how those who cannot remember the past are doomed to repeat it, ironic considering how his administration's neoliberal policies contributed to the conditions that helped put another despot as depraved as Marcos into power. The Marcoses are depicted as deluded oafs buoyed by the current of their unearned wealth, creating optics that somewhat distance the family from the atrocities they're responsible for, especially for those who are only learning about Imelda through this film. In one short scene, public school students casually repeat misinformation about Martial Law, mirrored in a sequence where Imelda makes the same claims to the period's secure and prosperous nature, set against archival images and footage of arrests and accounts of torture at the hands of police employed by the Marcoses. It is chilling, heartbreaking, infuriating, and makes it clear that despite Greenfield's documentary covering well-treaded ground, the message bears repeating. Viewed at the Philippine premier in UP Cine Adarna.
It’s one thing to watch this really well done documentary, but another thing to watch it in a theatre full of patriotic and passionate Filipino students. Everyone should go see this.
Great movie!! I learned so much, and kudos to the people behind this for creating this. The only thing I have against it is that it kinda comes off as Marcos vs Aquinos at times.

I’m so tired of living in the reality that The Kingmaker portrays. The cynical part of me thinks that, yes, films like this are great projects, but will they really matter much in the end? I fear that all they do is validate my political opinion and those who need to see it either won’t get to or won’t believe what it’s trying to convey.But then, there’s also that hopeful part of me that is stubborn even in exhaustion and wants to embrace every small win, every fighting chance the truth gets. For that, I’m grateful for The Kingmaker. Thank you to the crew for telling this story.My fingers are crossed that this documentary gets a wide release, that it gets uploaded to a streaming service so more can have access to it, or that it becomes required viewing in schools. The nation needs it. Badly.P.S. I’m writing this to remember: As the credits rolled in the screening I went to, people cried out in the darkness of the theater, chanting what we usually say when we’re protesting in the streets: “Never again, never again. Never again to Martial Law!” I hope we keep repeating it until everyone believes it to be true.

I think the most important thing that The Kingmaker did was to directly connect the Marcoses to Duterte - the money, the power, the influence, the strategy, the long con - in a way that is easy for people to follow and understand. Infuriating and frustrating to watch how this same story played out twice in our lifetimes.The main takeaway is proper education. Even I don’t remember being taught about the horrors of Martial Law in elementary and high school - I remember only memorizing that Marcos was the president that stayed the longest in power. Which is useless. If not for university, I probably would be as clueless as these kids in the movie, especially with how active the Marcoses are paying people to revise history to their advantage - which as we saw, our unreliable narrator Imelda Marcos has obviously started to believe and claim as historical facts. Also, how was it possible that after EDSA Revolution and TWO Aquino presidencies that there is still no memorial or museum detailing the atrocities of Martial Law?? This is why we always forget. Germany has its Holocaust memorial, and even Cambodia has the same for the Polpot genocides. How do we not have any? Why do we go to theme parks for field trips instead of a Martial Law museum? Sad thing is, it’s too late now. Not going to happen with the current government, after what we’ve seen in The Kingmaker. It is a testament to Greenfield’s dedication and craft that she was able to cover 50 years of Philippine history and show it in a very comprehensive and compelling structure, and managed to connect what has happened in the 70s to what is happening today by following the thread of money and power.

Lauren Greenfield has always had this strange fascination with showing how wealth corrupts people and how excess magnifies eccentricity. I went to an exhibit of hers sometime last year and found it interesting how so many of the portraits were of Imelda Marcos. Imagine my excitement, then, when I found out that the reason behind that was that Greenfield was making a documentary about Imelda. Finally, the wider world would know about the regime that tore our country into pieces. The Kingmaker is mostly successful at that, but it hardly treads new ground. She is portrayed in the documentary like she is portrayed in other international cultural works that feature her: eccentric, charismatic, having led a charmed life, having possessed 3000 shoes. In the end you have to wonder if it's Greenfield who's "tricking" Imelda into making this doc, or it's Imelda who's playing Greenfield.Strangely enough, the section that made it most interesting for me is what probably made it a weaker documentary. There is a 30 minute digression where we hardly see Imelda, and instead focus on the 2016 Vice Presidential elections. The family sees it as a chance to regain power and redeem their name, but their delusions of grandeur and desperation are only magnified. And while Bong Bong Marcos lost the elections, it is apparent that their power only grows stronger with the allegiance of Rodrigo Duterte. It feels less cohesive as a documentary as a result, but at least we're seeing something new. So is it good? I feel it is. Is it enough? Hardly. While there was a heartbreaking series of interviews with Martial Law victims, it is only implied that Imelda Marcos has something to do with this. Why was there no coverage of the convictions in international courts? Why was there no definite statement about the guilt of this woman? The Kingmaker is just another piece of cinema that perpetuates Imelda Marcos's legend. What I want to see is an outright condemnation of this woman, because she deserves nothing less. Never forget.

I've never heard so much aghast tutting in my life as from the audience at this screening. Imelda Marcos was the wife of Ferdinand Marcos, dictator of the Philippines from 1965 to 1986, when she and her husband fled into exile. But in the early 1990s her family returned to the Philippines and in the 2010s began it's return to the frontline of politics, seeking office for her son Bongbong. This film, with a tone of mounting horror, relates their appallingly successful efforts to return to power, the facts as frequently jaw-dropping as they are terrifying. For 90 minutes we watch this despicable cartoon villain throw herself a pity party while others suffer the consequences of her vomit-inducing luxury. The ripest metaphor at the films centre is the safari park she and her husband built, evicting hundreds of families from their island home to make way for animals poached from Africa. The film doesn't quite sell this as a metaphor for the political inbreeding, but it remains an incisive example of the cruelty and selfishness these vile humans spread. The initial catalogue of corruption, fraud, ignorance, exploitation and negligence gradually gives way to the insidious background whispers of genuine atrocities committed, before, in the final act, the curtain is fully drawn back and the extent and immediacy of the consequences of their unquenched thirst for power are lain bare and we finally grasp how urgent and real the threat these people pose democracy truly is. It is the rising panic of witnessing the wave of populism and post-truth over the last half a decade condensed down into 90 minutes. Initial disbelief mixed with a touch of amused mocking scorn, before the prickling sense of unease and ultimate bone chilling realisation that this is our reality now and these people, the worst of humanity, utterly devoid of self-reflection, empathy, intelligence or decency, really are running the world. It's a stunningly effective, if incomplete, account of our nightmare modern reality.

The Kingmaker: Or The Court's FoolSome people say there shouldn't be any platform anymore that would let Imelda Marcos speak. Anything that seems to come out of her mouth serves no higher purpose than to arouse her narcissism as nothing she says adds any real value to what we already know.Squeezing a reasonable statement from her is futile. This documentary would've worked without her. But the thing is: if given the chance for myself, I would've let it all be and made the documentary all about her relishing in her nonsense.No seriously, let me explain. From the cartoonish first shot of Imelda giving bills to the frenzied poor, The Kingmaker had a sense of a mockumentary in it that aims to highlight Imelda's delusions. For a second, I was suspicious about the prospect of this film hellbent on being pro-Imelda propaganda. But then it went somewhere and I realized: the film is not trolling us, it is trolling the Marcos matriarch herself. And in some moments of brilliant comedy, it seems that even she is trolling herself. It looks like I am watching The Office (2005), even though I never did see an episode of The Office. Or a Taika Waititi political satire akin to What We Do In The Shadows (2014), but tyrants instead of vampires, even though I never did see What We Do In The Shadows.By then you ask, "Is this reviewer full of himself? This is the Marcoses we are talking about for crying out loud! None of this is a laughing matter."And so I answer, "Comedy here is so intentional, you must have been an idiot or a hardcore Marcos fanatic to miss it."Greenwood's editing in The Kingmaker is so deliberate in making its subject ridiculous. There are times when scenes should've ended, but then she decides to linger into awkward pauses. Some cuts evoke absurd motifs that elicit restrained laughs. Restrained because they are positioned in instances where the situation programmed you to feel something else.I sure wish the documentary went in this direction completely. Relax, it did go into serious territory. And at this point, the film starts to falter. At least in a self-deprecating mockumentary, you would have focus. Greenwood's fault is that she tried to inject a little bit of everything in the narrative of The Kingmaker hence making the documentary boggled and frustratingly on the fence. It is obviously against tyranny, of course. But then again the documentary could've been appropriated and misread as a loving portrait of the old hag by some people. Which did happen for some appalling reason.By then you ask, "Is a mockumentary more susceptible to misinterpretation?" And so I stubbornly answer, "Shut up. I know. At least we had the unapologetic LOLs."However, as an informative piece that serves as an entry-level lesson to our history, The Kingmaker is highly successful. It even shed light on lesser known controversies that Imelda managed to get her hands on - the Calauit island conversion to an African safari and displacement of its indigenuos people. But you could still accuse the documentary for being pandering to liberals. It portrays the Aquinos as eventual heroes to history, as if the Cory Aquino administration saw significant improvement in the country's atmosphere. Which it didn't, as things arguably went worse.The documentary has an oversimplified black-and-white approach to the subject it tackles that could be a disservice to the complexities of our history, a possible by-product of Greenfield being an outsider.It works for students and foreigners, the latter of which is the real audience of the film. But to people who already made up their minds, there's only so much that this film could do.In a perfect world, The Kingmaker would educate more people on the truth of our history. And it would push loyalists to be more critical of their politics. Hell, in a perfect world, there would've been no need for The Kingmaker. But this isn''t a perfect world. In all seriousness, films like these are noble efforts and should be made more often. Only people should be more critical of what they watch.In lesser seriousness, let me end by cherishing this gem of a scene from the documentary: There's a scene where Imelda recounts how she hid diamonds in diapers to be taken with her as they try to leave Malacañang due to the People Power Revolution. "Diamonds in diapers,'' jokes Imelda. Then an awkward pause as she hopes for some laughs in the audience. No one laughed. Then I laughed because no one laughed. It's brilliant comedy.cinesensual2020.wordpress.com/2020/02/06/the-kingmaker-or-the-courts-fool/amp/

Lauren Greenfield's latest documentary about the Philippines' ex-first lady starts off as a darkly comic portrait of a delusional woman, but later turns into a disgusting tale of a loathsome monster's ambitions & lies.In  , we get a more personal look into the life of former first lady Imelda Marcos, their family's rose to power with her husband, the late Ferdinand Marcos being seated as the country's president. The documentary starts off a bit humorous, with Imelda introducing herself and her life before. The things she tells the camera are quite funny because it makes her look delusional- her actions are mostly eye-rolling (we spend a lot of time watching her give children with banknotes). It's full of spectacle, with archival footage of her hanging out with foreign leaders like Ronald Reagan, Fidel Castro, Saddam Hussein, and Mao Zedong. But as soon as the interviews with Martial Law survivors enters the picture, you realize that she's an unreliable narrator- the story she's been telling us was leaning towards a certain narrative aiming to cleanse our view towards her, the Marcos family, and Martial Law in general.Imelda is obviously using melodrama to get the poor's sympathy- a strategic story to support their return to power as she & her children, Bongbong & Imee, try to climb the ladder back to the government. What's worse is that they are also trying to revise our country's history, by changing what has transcribed in the past and teaching these fake information to the youth. At one point, some kids were asked what they know about Martial Law. Their answers stupefied me, with all of them saying that it was a 'golden' era for the Philippines. George Santayana was right: those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.: Definitely a must watch for everyone, with its sharp and biting depiction of Marcos' regime and its connection with today's fascist regime of Duterte.

I'm still angry so this might not be as objective. It's uncomfortable and infuriating, knowing that this family who has blantantly abused this country (and still do!) is still not held responsible for their numerous crimes to the state. I find it an interesting direction choice to use Imelda as an unreliable narrator and then juxtaposing that with archival footage and firsthand testimonies of people affected by the 1972 Martial Law, which diametrically opposes what the Marcos family claims. The access Greenfield and her team had with the family is also worth noting because it's quite obvious that they're all putting a show—all part of their scheme to revise history and put themselves back into power. But we know better than that. Greenfield used that access to present something beyond the Marcoses' "show"—families and villagers displaced from their homes because the Marcoses want their very own island zoo, thousands of victims of human rights abuses, even the people working for them that are treated like pawns instead of human beings. But it's a pity they still tried to play it safe. If you're going to give people like the mythmaker a platform, you need to be clear and firm in your stance instead of staying neutral.It's very important to process the film after watching it. People who saw this film should note that all of this isn't about the Marcos-Aquino family feud or a fight between political parties. It's about how this government continually oppresses its people for the sake of vanity and greed. Philippine Premiere · UPFI Cine Adarna

To a person who doesn't know much about Marcos rule in the Philippines, the ingenious switch in tone and perspective that Greenfield plays will come as a shock. However as a person who has heard from my mother, and other family and friends from the Philippines how fucked up the Marcos regime was, my skin was crawling the moment I saw Imelda tearing up as she was handing out pesos to poor people on the street.The doc does well in setting us up to root for Imelda and the Marcoses, and then swiftly pull the rug from under the viewers. This is done by lessening interview footage of the Marcoses themselves and favoring the interviews that are anti-Marcos, a very simple way of switching perspective. When it becomes clear that a big portion of the money that they have was stolen, that was basically the final nail in the coffin of the doc’s case against the family. This kind of disillusionment, or whatever refusal to accept the truth that Imelda Marcos displays throughout the film and throughout her campaigning with Bongbong is frightening. It is especially frightening because people in the Philippines are starting to forget and forgive the horrible past that her husband inflicted upon the nation. Burn them down.

Letting Imelda Marcos tell her heavily sanitized and self-pitying story of her shady past (with commentary from, among others, old American coots who helped keep her husband's regime in power), the director lets her hang herself with her own lies even as her family tries to claw back power in the equally degenerate Duterte era. If the shoes fit, wear 'em.

I saw The Kingmaker in UP Film Institute during the 34th EDSA Anniversary, so the milieu made it feel like the movie is preaching to the choir at this point, so I was kind of disappointed that there was little nuance with how it talks about the connections between our current issues and the Marcoses. What's funny, I think, is that in its attempt to show the Marcoses' humanity—or lack thereof—it did not let enough voice from the masses to speak. That's why my favorite parts were when it touched on the Calauit Safari, because it puts the two classes at odds with each other (and how order both in nature and in humans was threatened because of it). Still, I think it's an important film especially for people who are learning about the family's atrocities for the first time. It would not win the conversion of the diehards or the undecided, but it does solidify one fact and one battlecry: #NeverAgain to a Marcos in power.

When people think of Imelda Marcos, usually the first thing that comes to mind is her 3,000 pairs of luxury shoes, her luxury fashion and lavish lifestyle. She was also the first lady of Manila, married to the president Ferdinand. They were in power from 1965 until their removal in 1986. They're widely believed to have illegally amassed a wealth of billions of U.S. dollars, all of which has never been recovered, holding the Guinness World Record for greatest government robbery. She has since been charged with her dealings and corruption, as well as disqualified from holding any public office. But was later cleared of all previous charges on appeal, and still continues to live in Manila.In this documentary, she's very much still living the lavish lifestyle and gladly shows everyone her priceless collection of luxuries, including paintings and sculptures. It paints a disquieting portrait of the divisive controversial public figure, thanks to Lauren Greenfield's direction, writing and exploration.

Attended the Cebu (Robinson's Galleria) premiere of The Kingmaker. The Kingmaker reminded me of the power of documentary. Consciously in a theater of audiences with a wide age range, the screening made me reflect on films: Birth of a Nation (1915), Triumph of the Will (1935), Give Up Tomorrow (2011), BlacKkKlansman (2018). I reflected that films are avenue to make people think for themselves. What are the differences between these films? It is important to be informed and to question the information we receive. Regardless of who was born on which political era, we ought to learn from what happened in the past regardless on the level of "affiliation" we have with it. To be informed of the past is one step ahead avoid repeating history.

"Perception is real, and the truth is not."These terrifying words come from the delusional Imelda Marcos, whose influence on politics in the Philippines is scary. The Kingmaker interviews Marcos at length, only for it to become clear that she is a greedy liar seeking to play the victim. So basically Imelda Marcos is the Eva Peron of the Philippines but more sinister and eccentric. Both Eva and Imelda, beautiful women who came from the poor and rose to power beside their dictator husband, are similarly fascinating people who wield such influence that they start to believe they were saviors or "mothers" of their people. Plus they have great musicals based on their lives. The interesting thing about Lauren Greenfield's "The Kingmaker" is how the tone of the film shifts midway. The first half of the doc shines on the past, presenting us with Imelda's many eccentricities and extravagant lifestyle that were so funny to learn about. But it then shifts into serious politics of the present where we get to learn that Imelda is still wielding power by helping to elect his son into the Vice-Presidency. It's Greenfield's way of forboding how the country is doomed to repeat history.
fucking terrifying

"Perception is real. The truth is not."It's Women's History Month. Love her or hate her, Imelda Marcos is definitely a woman who made history.In short time I'm going to work my way backwards through documentarian Lauren Greenfield's filmography, starting with her most recent film, The Kingmaker, profiling Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of The Philippines. Notable for far more than just her epic shoe collection, Marcos held the reigns of power behind-the-scenes during her family's time in office, and now has hopes to return to the presidential mansion.Greenfield's style in this film is to allow Marcos to tell her own history and her own story at first. We follow her in-person as she is interviewed, talking about her family, upbringing, and rise to power in the mid-1960s. For over two decades, her husband Ferdinand ruled with her at his side, a political power broker and key agent in diplomacy, using her striking looks and infectious charm to be as close to other world leaders -- often conservative, often dictatorial -- as her husband ever was. Famously catching Ferdinand cheating on her with tape recorder under the bed, which she used as blackmail to get what she wanted later, she grew in prestige and influence into the 80s as the family lived like extravagant royalty amidst a nation suffering in abject poverty. It was the 1986 People Power revolution (and election of Corazon Aquino) which forced them from office and exiled the family from ever ruling The Philippines again.Of course, the Marcos regime ruled with an iron fist in a military dictatorship, and gradually through The Kingmaker the stories of others -- those affected by the imposition of martial law, the families evicted from their homes to the Marcos family could build and renovate at will, the torture victims and political prisoners of innumerable amounts -- come to the fore, and the real truth is revealed about Imelda. That is, Greenfield allows her to be an unreliable narrator, and brings in members of the Aquino family and other opponents to counter her fabrications and exaggerations, like a form of fact checking. Along with her son Bongbong who Imelda wishes to see back in the presidential palace again -- and who probably likes Parasite exactly twice as much as you do -- the two craft a fantastical tale of their birthright to rule, while everyone else fights against their corruption and misdeeds as the loving Marcos clan cozies up to current sociopathic president Duterte.Now in her late 80s, Imelda appears unrepentant and even in denial of any of her family's actions. And why would she admit them? She still maintains fabulous wealth that was shipped offshore and retained after exile, still flaunting it in the face of today's Filipino people and using it to further Bongbong's campaign. In a bizarre state of denial about the years of horror her family brought to The Philippines, Imelda plays the victim and twists the facts to beg for sympathy; unfortunately it has worked in some ways, stealing billions from the country while many Filipinos suffered.Greenfield has explored themes of wealth, privilege, and bewildering ignorance of power and influence before, and The Kingmaker does that effectively. The doc plays with a linear timeline a little, and the shifting stories can make it difficult to follow if you don't already have knowledge of the era. I imagine anyone not from the Philippines and especially anyone under 30 might need more background information about this history to fully grasp the evil of the Marcos regime and impact for decades more, as well as how it's profoundly affected the current Duterte era. This film though is an excellent start.Added to The Best Documentary Films of 2019.Added to Lauren Greenfield ranked.

wow. what a chilling, moving portrait of a power-hungry woman.i remember crying at around the end of the movie. when the latter half transitioned to the repercussions of the marcos regime at present. my eyes started to water at the descriptions of torture during martial law, was crying during the scene of the children talking about the revised version of history of the marcos era, and was full-on sobbing during the highlighting of the EJKs under duterte. it brought me back to the beginnings of my activist life—the pain and the anger that our country experienced. i hope this never gets forgotten. i hope that the latter half of the portrait is the one we remember the marcoses by. i hope that we will continue to look at them as the power-hungry, dynastic despots they are that continue to manipulate the filipino people to shape their world into their distorted version of beauty. it's a chilling documentary, and i admire the effect it had during its screenings. when the audience would lightning protest, say "never again" and "marcos not a hero" at the top of their lungs after the movie, that is hopeful. i guess the white people who watched and were underwhelmed would never understand just how much it means to our nation being torn apart by this family and the other families who coalesce to their power.

I am not a PolSci student nor have the credibility to speak up properly about politics and I don't know alot about this topic so I'm glad there is a proper documentary about this. This post is very long. If u have the time to read it go ahead. I'd like to start off by saying I absolutely love the camerawork here. I love studying cinematography and hope to be a cinematographer someday and I must say that knowing this is a documentary, where the shots are more spontaneous and thinking of where to point the camera or keep what's in the frame is alot more crucial and I guess more thought is happening whilst operating it. There were 3 parts that I loved the camera work so much. 1. Imelda was at her garden flexing her framed photos and pics one up right in the middle. I guess her arm or dress snagged the other frames in the background that it went crashing down like dominoes. She watched frames crash with NO. FUCKING. EMPATHY. OR SIGN OF CONCERN –– WALA!!!! She just fucking looked at it fall, brushed it off and continued speaking about whoever the fuck she was with. While that was happening (and this is where I talk abt camera work) the cam ZOOOOMS out and shows one of her house help bending down to pick up the shattered pieces of her "precious framed photos of her """""friends""""""" Tangina nasugatan ba si Kuya?????? My heart goes for people employed under her, they don't deserve that. 2. Also with Imelda's house help. She was flexing this other HUGEASS picture frame of a newspaper clipping and she asked her househelp to hold it up. She was hiding herself from the camera but had one eye peeping in between the crook of her elbow. I saw her emotions and just felt so sorry for her. Idk what she was actually feeling ah but Idk it just feels wrong. 3. Imelda was again flexing this part of her house with again EXTRAVAGANT paintings and sculptures, the camera was at a medium wide which already was showing enough of the venue. But the cameraperson zoomed out slowly to reveal one of Imelda's house help trying to inch their way out of the frame to hide. But as he tried to inch himself out, the camera kept him in frame. I saw the back and forth and it just goes to show how they feel unworthy???? (for the lack of a better term) ALSO WOW JUST LAUREN GREENFIELD UR MIND I STAN She beautifully crafted this docu to reveal the truth about the Marcoses but not as an IN UR FACE U SUK type of way. But in a way that really digs deep into ur psyche and just makes u feel the anger to ur core. Correct me if I'm wrong, but If u watch this documentary it can be interpreted in 2 main ways. If you're a Marcos supporter you'd watch this and see scenes you agree. You'd agree with Imelda when she'd say she's the Matriarchal Saviour of the Philippines, you'd say Martial Law was a wonderful time for the PH. But if you had common sense, or you know,,,, in the eyes of the well informed, we really know what this docu is about and I will absolutely hate them for it. In the end it states that they're slowly finding their way back into PH Politics and I just cannot stand knowing we've got another batch of them. Okay. So as someone who is a Filipino fully knowing and aware of context of the Marcos Regime as well the current situation in the Philippines, this was nothing new. That being said, it did reinforce even more how how the Marcoses and Imelda in particular incredibly detached and self-absorbed to the point that they see no faults in themselves and their motivations and actions. They are genuinely the worst and it is saddening to see how quickly they have rose back to prominence. The film does a good job of building up Imelda as someone who at first seems okay only to later destroy her later on, particularly the sequences wherein Imelda would say one thing then would immediately be contradicted afterwards; it might be an effective way of getting the message across for someone who may be unaware of PH politics to not be sympathetic for them. And in the end, they are really the audience of this documentary. It scratches the surface with regards to the history of that time and circumstances of the now, and that's okay if it was intended to be that way. For me, however, it's just a frustrating watch (not the film's fault of course).

Been waiting to activate my showtime trial for this, and it was definitely worth it. Especially timely now given that my aunt recently told me her experience under Marcos' martial law made coronavirus shelter-in-place preparation feel second nature. While it's definitely not a feel good movie, there's something awful and amazing about watching Imelda spin a distorting web around history. Greenfield doesn't confront her directly, but then again I don't know how she could. Instead we get the other view of things through interviews, which might get at the truth, but don't let us see the delusional/masterful reinterpretation of the past that Imelda employs, which is the real star of the show. In fact, the central question here might be which side of the fine line she is on: is she consciously evil, or does she truly believe the things she is saying? And of course, does it even matter, given the real, horrible fallout of her family's actions.

Very interesting and entertaining documentary on Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines who lived in a lavish lifestyle by plundering her nations wealthy, The Kingmaker is an in depth feature that chronicles her legacy. I found the film to be very good and shows that Marcos was quite deceptive and dishonest. It's quite an interesting film to watch and the way things are presented on-screen makes the viewer form his or hers own opinion on Marcos. The film is quite fascinating in what it does, yet I think more things could have been added to the film too. It's quite in depth, but the film could have been a bit longer too. Regardless the documentary covers enough ground to be a very thorough feature on its subject, and it is a very entertaining movie. The Kingmaker is entertaining from start to finish and the film features very good archival footage as well as interviews with Imelda Marcos and those who know her. We get both sides of the story and it is a well constructed genre film. The Kingmaker is worth watching and if you are interested in the subject, you'll find everything that you want out of this film. For what it is it is a good, well made documentary movie that is a very entertaining effort that focuses on a very controversial figure and although not a classic documentary, it manages to be worth watching because Imelda Marcos is quite a polarizing figure.

"They found no skeletons. Only beautiful shoes" is just one of the many striking and unbelievable lines that came from former Philippine First Lady Imelda Marcos in Laura Greenfield's documentary "The Kingmaker". The line exhibits the nonagenarian's lavish perspective despite living in a third world country that suffered from the regime of her late husband and dictator Ferdinand Marcos. Greenfield's documentary shows how "imeldific (ostentatiously extravagant)" the mindset of Imelda despite the numerous human rights violations and embezzlement that happened during the Marcos regime. After all of her controversial past, it is beyond belief how Imelda is firm to declare that the Philippines was in its glory during Martial LawGreenfield portrays Imelda as someone who has a savior complex. Imelda believes that being the first lady means being a mother to everyone so she wants nothing but the best for Filipinos. She visits the streets while aboard her car and gives out money to children. She goes to the hospital and distributes huge bucks like its just coins to her. But being a mother is beyond giving money for Imelda. She wants to convert the country into a paradise that will be looked up by other countries. "The Kingmaker" gives light to the usually undiscussed Calauit Safari Park in Palawan. Imelda was in awe of Africa's beautiful safaris so she bought giraffes, zebras, monkeys, and more African animals and placed them on a small island. The film shows Imelda's inhumane mind when some residents of Calauit island detailed how the military evicted them in favor of the animals that are not even natives in the Southeast Asian Country. It later revealed that the animals there are not properly taken care of because of the absence of a veterinarian who specializes in safari animals. It's an antithesis to Imelda's own perception of being a mother to everything in the Philippines, showing that she's only obsessed with the aesthetic surfaceImelda has also risen to a new societal power when she was shown leading infrastructure projects and buying expensive New York buildings. At some point, it was also suggested that Imelda was the one running the country as her husband is falling ill. "The Kingmaker" shows Imelda as not just a first lady or the "mother" of Filipinos. She is also a puppeteer who can control everyone with the strings made out of Php 1,000 bills.Greenfield was able to show Imelda as an out-of-touch personality who still believes that her family has the solution to everything. However, one has got to ask if Greenfield wants to convince pro-Marcos and moderates to pick the other side. If she has that intention, unfortunately, The Kingmaker" will just serve to them as a "hate piece" to the Marcos supporters and those who are in between. In fact, they may have encountered the 2003 documentary about Imelda but they are still firm on what they believe is right. Moreover, getting Marcos' opponents such as Vice President Leni Robredo and former President Noynoy Aquino (son of slain senator and fierce Marcos critic Benigno Sr.) as the opposing voices to Imelda will more likely fail to convince a lot of people. Hence, the discourse between the Pro- and Anti-Marcos will be just filled with tiring justifications of the authorities' actions."Perception is real and the truth is not," Imelda said in the documentary. So, the question now is "Which perception is Greenfield trying to appeal?". Because if she's appealing to Marcos supporters, the documentary may lack in showing new information on Imelda's ridiculousness. Maybe except for the Calauit safari. The director could have focused her story on that island and meticulously unravel the fate of the residents and the animals there caused by Imelda's shallow vision of a perfect and paradise-like society.
Maybe its only flaw is letting Imelda open her mouth.

The greatest performance of Imelda Marcos. Deserves an award for being the most conniving, manipulative, and self-centered human... or is she even considered one? In her old age she's still convinced that she gave birth to the greatest era of the Philippines. Bong bong looks like a pet more than a son. You can see how he always seeks for his mother's approval. Imee just looks like the cheap dolls you get at divi — purely plastic. She even got her mother's big hair.Director Lauren Greenfield's documentary not only shows the two sides of politics in the Philippines, but also explains how perception is not that easy to deceive. From watching this film, I kept asking questions like "How do the people not see it?" or "How did she get away with it?". Honestly, Annalise Keating should take a lecture from her. You will see how quick and strategic the mind of the former first lady is which made things always go her way. I guess that's where her fallacious line "Perception is real, truth is not" comes in. We often attach ourselves to our beliefs and create layers of lies in order to protect them. There were a few significant events that were missed from the film. However, from what was shown I think it was enough to make you understand and even empathize on behalf of the victims. I hope that more people get a chance to watch and educate themselves of how power should not be in the hands of heartless people.Book recommendation: The Conjugal Dictatorship of Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos by Primitivo Mijares
I love everything Lauren Greenfield does, and this was no exception. Her photography is stunning as always.

I feel super conflicted about this one. It's fascinating and I love Lauren Greenfield.I just feel like ... more than her other docs, this story just really got away from her in a way that she wasn't qualified to handle.This is ... well, it's objectively empathetic toward Imelda Marcos in that it just shows her for who she is. And unsurprisingly, she's an ambitious, power-hungry person with delusions she's doing the right thing. This documentary is not trying to make you like her, but just understand her. And what I understand about her is not ... good. I really went into this thinking I was maybe going to end up liking her or at least having some sympathy for her, like she was just misunderstood. My takeaway was absolutely the opposite. She's worse than I thought she was.But as the political situation in the Philippines changed, I think Greenfield wasn't really equipped to keep up. It became more of a news story rather than a people story. And that's not her fault! As much as I think she's good at setting out to make one documentary and then ends up making another, in this case, it didn't quite work. I just don't know if she quite had the background to put all of this in the proper context.It's definitely worth watching, though, and the parts of it that work do work really well. And the parts that don't work are still pretty good.
