Before watching this documentary, I was afraid that it will paint the Marcoses and the late dictator’s term in a good light; that it might be another attempt of the Marcoses’ on historical revisionism. During elementary school, the Marcos regime is dubbed as “The Golden Age of the Philippines”. The usual narratives are: the Philippines was one of the richest countries in Asia; when Marcos declared martial law, there was peace and order; and that he ended poverty. A lot of students are growing up thinking that he was the best president the Philippines ever had. Even I, at one point, believed that. Fast forward to high school, the Marcos dictatorship is once again discussed along with martial law. There I learned that media companies are shut down to censor information, and that he imprisoned his political opponents. However, accounts of torture and murder are not discussed. As I grow older, I encounter more documentaries and articles proving that during his term was not “The Golden Age of the Philippines” (though it might be for his cronies). Now that information is more accessible with the help of the internet, more information regarding the crimes of the Marcoses are revealed. I remember watching a video on Facebook wherein young people who grew up believing that Marcos is the best president of the Philippines are sat down with a victim of martial law. After the young ones tell why they thought Marcos was good president, the victims then narrate how they were tortured by Marcos’ men. However, the internet has also given a platform to Marcos apologists to propagate the narrative that the Marcos regime was best because of his infrastructure projects. This documentary has let Imelda tell her story without letting her control the narrative. It changed my perception on her position as a first lady. She was more than a lavish woman who indulges in shoes. She was more than an accessory to her husband. Her image as the muse of Manila has helped Marcos ascend into power, and helped him in connecting with other world leaders. Until now, she’s one of the reasons why her children (even after all they have done to this country) has been elected into government positions. Hoping that more people, especially Filipinos, are given the chance to watch this.

I was 10 or 11 years old in 1986 when the Marcos family fled the Philippines. I knew nothing of martial law or potential human rights atrocities. I got my news like everyone else--from Johnny Carson. Imelda Marcos' shoe collection provided a bevy of fodder for late night comedians of the era. I'm surprised that no clips were inserted into this documentary.I found this film to be fine, but a bit disappointing over all. It was one I was very much looking forward to since it made the rounds at film festivals last year. I never get to go to these festivals, but I try to look at the programming guide and make a schedule as if I was going. I always tried to find room for this film in my make believe schedule. Luckily for me, this film was available as part of a free Showtime weekend on Sling, so my wait wasn't as long as it could have been.I think the film's structure is its biggest obstacle. Not presenting the film mainly in chronological order hurts the storytelling in my opinion. I think that the film would have been better served by showing some present day Imelda then going back to her marriage and really focus on the time of the Marcos presidency/dictatorship. I never really fully grasped the politics of the country based on this documentary. The film kind of jumps around too much to paint a full picture of what was happening to the Filipino people.Perhaps the most egregious part of the film comes at the end titles. There is a lot of interesting information that is thrown up there to read instead of using time to show it on film. We spend a lot of time with Leni Roberdo (who ran against Bongbong Marcos for Vice Presdient), but then learn she suddenly have all of these charges against her by a suspect President! I want to know more about that! Why even bother including it?Despite the, in my opinion, lack of focus the film seems to present, it is compelling to hear the thoughts of Imelda. She remains one of the most infamous people of the late 20th century. But I'm not sure that this film ever allows the viewer to fully know her.

It’s a cliffsnotes version of the last near decade in the Philippines, and I do think this is the type of cultural artifact that Filipino documentarians cannot really package and broadcast - at the very least for now.The docu’s biggest strength is the way it captures Imelda’s twisted way of thinking. It’s very natural for her to downplay a lot of history, and to drive the narrative convincingly. It’s the same power you see in archival footage of “the Conjugal Dictatorship”, and the same power that is insinuated as puppetry- or at least sponsorship- for the currently sitting Duterte. The nugget quote “Perception is real and the truth is not” is the ironic essence of our time, delivered by the patron saint of Filipino boomers herself. It’s a reminder that what seems new and surprising in the valley of fake news, is just what is and what has always been to a certain breed of alligator.It should be noted that the docu scopes out a lot of nuance, atrocities and products of her Edifice complex in favor of an introductory contrast between the Marcos era and their rise back to power today. Yes, it includes heart wrenching testimonies of essential Martial Law era dissenters, and their harrowing experiences are just the tip of the bloody iceberg. But understandably, you can’t package all nuance into a digestible document, and the target audience is composed of non-Filipinos - but letting them know about the basic stuff is still pretty important.But I think the most important thing they gloss over is the corruption and/or callousness of what came after (it is mentioned, but it could’ve used a few more minutes) and why a nostalgic rose colored filter has colored many of those who lived through the toppling of the Marcoses. There’s a lot in the docu that many critics of the Marcoses already put forward, and a lot that his staunch loyalists deny (or recontextualize), and it’s unlikely to change local perceptions. For those who live in the thick of the topic at hand, a different approach to the documentation of this era seems more fitting.In two more years, the Philippines will either experience another political shift, or lead up to this slow burn of a Marcos return. It’s hard to predict what the Imeldific Kingmaker’s strategy is going to be about, but it likely will be the opposite of beautiful.

"Perception is real, the truth is not."It's a shocking admission, even by Imelda Marcos' standards. But what passes as lazy dialogue from a feature film becomes a damning confession in a documentary. Lauren Greenfield continues her treatise on the corrupting influence of wealth and power. But while Greenfield is retreading familiar territory in The Kingmaker, the sheer size and scope of this semi-biopic dwarfs any of her previous work. Imelda Marcos is a familiar subject for the Filipino people, but Greenfield recontextualizes the delusional former first Lady from within a nation run by President Duterte. The Marcos family is still as narcissistic as ever, and to no one's surprise, is still trying to weasel their way back into power.It's a story the Filipino people should already know by heart, but considering our goldfish memory, it's a story worth retelling until the end of time.As a documentary, The Kingmaker says nothing new. But it does say something important. As a Filipino, however -- tangina mo Marcos balik mo pera namin.
an important view

The documentary tries to present two sides of a coin, but ultimately reveals itself to be slanted in the right direction for humane reasons. It is political, gripping, and deeply personal to the Filipino's struggle for justice. The film becomes even more relevant with a narrative on Duterte and how everything potentially ties to the Marcoses' bid for power again. While I would have preferred there was less of Imelda being given the avenue to try and twist history, I know only the ignorant can be fooled by her delusions. Contrary to Imelda's belief, the truth exists and manifests itself to discerning people so that hopefully, we can truly say #NeverAgain.

Here is my position: we should never put Imelda Marcos in front of a camera. We should never give her access to any platform whatsoever, because it's just another opportunity for her to spout her lies, all shrouded under the guise of her being this doddering old woman with strange philosophies about beauty and mothering. I've been hearing her say the same goddamn things for my entire life, and this movie reveals nothing new in its extended conversations with this immortal tyrant.The film does actively undercut the things that she's saying, but it's an extra step. We do not need to talk to the Marcoses to explore their evil. We do not gain insight by spending time in their palatial homes, with their art and their clothes and all the aspirational bullshit that makes them weird antiheroes in this broken oligarchic society.The best parts of this film are the parts where it talks to victims, where it talks to the poor. The film tries to be clever with its juxtapositions, but the end effect is that it still gives voice to the lies, still allows a truly evil person to revise history. It opens up the possibility of accusations of bias, and letting them play the victim yet again when all they've ever done is victimize the Filipino.There are no two sides when telling the story of the Marcoses. They stole from the country, and tortured and killed thousands of people. Somewhere along the way, the film seems to come to the realization that Imelda isn't the harmless old biddy that they thought she was. But it's too late. They talked to her, and gave her yet another chance to say the vile things she's always been saying.

Never have I felt more building anger towards the Marcoses and the Duterte regime after finishing The Kingmaker. My blood is boiling with rage at the injustice of it all. I don’t leave overly political statements in my reviews, but just for the sake of this insightful and enlightening documentary—this fascist regime has to be taken down and tore apart limb from limb. Shame on the Marcoses for throwing this country into active disarray. Fuck this family (and fuck you, Sandro, for being a glorified idiot).

Marcoses set up an illusion that poverty can be eradicated with beauty and elegance, and most importantly, ignorance.

The Kingmaker feels like a double-edged sword.On one hand this documentary exposes Imelda Marcos for the thieving liar and delusional old bitch that she is. Lauren Greenfield, the director, uses a careful juxtaposition of Imelda's outlandish pronouncements with testimonies from people who suffered and continues to suffer under their power to further highlight how ridiculous and unrepentant she is. It also does a good job in exposing how they perpetrated mediocrity and impunity through her children who are now trying to reclaim the political clout that they lost years ago. There is an undercurrent of rage in the entire documentary, as we slowly see this rotten family rebuild their reputation through deceit and political connections. It ends on a terrifying note: she and her family insist that we forget the past and move on to pave the way for their return. Yet on the other hand, it also needs to be said that this documentary also gave another opportunity for the Marcoses to repeat their lies. It humanized them in a way, and made it seem that there is another "unheard" side to the narrative of our nation. As one of the activists tortured during Martial Law said, "I don't have an answer why we allow Imelda to open her mouth." And that's exactly what this movie did. It allowed her to speak freely. Bad publicity is still publicity for these vultures. I am afraid they can twist this in their favor, knowing how cunning they are and how ruthless their propaganda machine is. I commend it for reminding us of who our enemies are, but it's also a documentary that I wish didn't get made. It's mere existence means we haven't learned our lesson yet.

Greenfield appeared more fascinated in than critical of Imelda as a singular political force. After all, Imelda made her out-of-touch decisions and delusions of grandeur unequivocally on her own terms. So when Imelda is framed as a “kingmaker” (for supporting Duterte, among other reasons), it fails to capture the frustrating circularity of Philippine politics; The Kingmaker disappoints inasmuch as it glosses over the political context Imelda thrives in and one that placed her back in power.This film is paler in comparison to - and most of the time repetitive of - Diaz’s Imelda (2003). For an unrepentant and corrupt political figure that has never been held to account, you can’t go soft; you go all out. When Imelda said, “sometimes it helps that you are not taken too seriously”, Greenfield seemed to agree with her.

“Perception is real, the truth is not.”Well, ain't that a 2010 quote if ever there was one.The Kingmaker is a documentary about the life and times of one Imelda Marcos, famous First Lady of the Philippines for 21 years. I was generally unaware of her history and her influence going into this, though I'm pretty sure I had an inkling about the shoe thing.The Kingmaker begins innocently enough, starting with Imelda herself. She goes through her history, her upbringing, her marriage, and her pride in the political power she had. She proclaims herself to be "The mother of the nation," a symbol of hope to the masses. People love her, she says, and we're given no reason to think otherwise.Regular documentary viewers may know where this is going; we're being lulled into a false sense of security, before the filmmakers blindside us with a right hook and say, "No, actually, this is how all that really went down."And how. It becomes clear as The Kingmaker goes on that what we're seeing is a portrait of a raging narcissist, an inconsiderate dictator, and, in all likelihood, a mass-murderer. The film is directed by Lauren Greenfield, and while I've not seen any of her previous documentaries, I can tell looking at their descriptions - The Queen of Versailles in 2012, and Generation Wealth in 2018 - that The Kingmaker falls right into her wheelhouse of examining and deconstructing the insanity of the rich and powerful.Right from the start, Imelda Marcos cuts a fascinating, and infuriating, figure. The first thing we see her do in the film is ride around in her luxury limousine, passing by scenes of abject poverty and complaining, "This used to be my little paradise. In my time, there were no beggars." Somehow, I don't believe her. Later, we see her handing out giant wads of money to random passersby. This is something we see her do a bit, and we come to understand it's a regular occurrence; she will frequently walk around, or ride around in busses, handing out money to the impoverished masses, who obviously respond with gratitude. That's how she wins their hearts and minds, see.The film plays a tricky game with Imelda Marcos. Right from the start, we're encouraged to not take her at face value; the film highlights the inherently ridiculous nature of her appeals to mass popularity, and her assurance that she's just as powerful and beloved as she was in her prime, when none of that is clearly true. Basically, she begins the film as a clown, a totally ridiculous figure ripe for mockery. Not knowing the extent of her vileness, I assumed that this was a documentary about how a country was damaged through incompetence.Imelda Marcos begins The Kingmaker as a joke, and ends it as a monster. As the net of the documentary's eye widens, and more and more talking heads emerge to tell their stories of what it was actually like under Marcos dictatorship, the film repeatedly returns to Imelda's silent, resilient gaze, and we're forced to ask: "Surely, there's no way you didn't know about this, right? After all, you were just bragging about how you were the secret power behind your husband. Surely, you knew?"In many ways, The Kingmaker is the perfect documentary for our time. because Imelda Marcos IS a clown; she's a vain, pompous, egotistical fool who at one point insists to the camera that she could've solved all the world's problems, because all the world leaders just found her so charming. But behind all that, there's this twisted image of a frilly despot, lounging away as her country starves, and her people are tortured. By her.The Kingmaker I think does an excellent job at painting Imelda Marcos into a corner from which she can't escape, using cutaway evidence and cross-testimony, all while keeping her unaware that this "puff-documentary" is actually a hit piece. I appreciate that there's never really a moment that The Kingmaker allows her to seem sincere; even when the extent to her monstrosity isn't quite apparent, she comes across as a complete egomaniac, with way too much while her country has way too little.But then things get serious, fast. There are hints as to something darker lurking under the surface early on; how she talks about the period of martial law being a golden age, or how she keeps the body of her husband perfectly preserved behind glass, which is just a horrific image. But then we hear about how she imported all these exotic animals to an island, only to abandon the project after the animals proved to be more trouble than they were worth. Those animals are still there, as cross-breeding catastrophes. We hear about the Tunnel of Love, which was built by Imelda's husband for her, and then became the name of a particularly grisly method of torture. And we follow a series of money trails, the end result of which is that the Marcos family seems to have been robbing their country blind.Even more worryingly, the film will frequently cut to the present, where we see Imelda masterminding her son's campaign to be Vice President of the Philippines (Vice President there is different than in America; it's a separate election than that of the President, and the VP generally has more responsibility than they do here), with the money she seems to have stolen directly from the people. It's here that the film begins to lose me a little; by playing with nonlinear chronology, it sometimes becomes hard to track the exact order of events as they happened. And every once in a while, I did find myself wondering, "I wonder what was happening in the rest of the world at around this time?" But the film does succeed at painting a portrait of wealthy insanity, damningly well. The image of Imelda Marcos, now elderly, on the cusp of re-achieving political dominance and still in complete denial about her family's evil legacy, is appropriately chilling.“There are so many things in the past that we should forget. In fact, it’s no longer there.”

After watching Queen of Versailles, I wanted some more documentaries in my life and went on to look at more of director Lauren Greenfield's work. The Kingmaker popped up and had actually been recommended to me before so I decided to watch. I had a VERY surface level understanding of the political world this documentary showcased. I think this is an example of really great, holistic documentary making. I came out of this with a much greater understanding of the topic without it being too bogged down in talking head interviews. The emotions kept hitting and there was just a really powerful storytelling arc put into place here. One of the best documentaries I've seen in a long time.
The Kingmaker is an eye-opener for what happened in the past and what could happen in the future.

"Perception is real, and the truth is not."All I knew about Imelda Marcos was that she was basically the Filipina version of Jackie Kennedy, with her terno sleeves and thousands of pairs of shoes. When the documentary starts, she talks about her role as a First Lady, her husband's infidelities, and her commitment to her country, not as a political official, but as a mother figure. As the film continues, it's clear that Marcos's "mothering" of the nation was nothing more than widespread mismanagement of government funds, corruption, and human rights abuses. I think that the documentary could have introduced this "side" of her sooner, because the first half an hour leads us to believe that she was a formidable force in Philippine politics who was relegated to the sidelines because of her sex. Maybe that's the editing, but it probably has something to do with Marcos's masterful manipulation skills. She knows what to say and how to spin situations, so the documentary is much more powerful when juxtaposing her propaganda with the testimony of real-life witnesses to her crimes. Crimes which, unfortunately, are not explored with much depth. I wish more time had been spent on martial law and her money laundering. However, the half an hour spent on the Marcos family's attempts to re-infiltrate Philippine politics is incredible. They've worked with the current president to arrest their opposition, jail the VICE PRESIDENT, and rig the Supreme Court, all to make Marcos Jr. the president. Imelda Marcos mentions that the country is full of "forgiving" people who love her because she was a "good mother" to them. I hope that, despite all their forgiving, the people don't forget."Now is the important thing, and the past is the past. There are so many things in the past that we should forget. In fact, it's no longer there."also, shoutout to Jocelyn Pook for an incredible score !!!

Being first generation American Filipino, I always crave any film that has to do with the motherland. Anything Asian really, perhaps because of the lack of representation? ahem ahem. And I notice there really aren’t many documentaries available about the Philippines (MAJOR lack of representation, being that we’re ALL over America and the world AHEM AHEM). But I digress.This documentary is a reflection of Philippines’ political history. It focuses on the reign of the Marcoses. Growing up in Hawaii I would here praises of the Marcoses, so I had a biased opinion of them already. But this documentary sheds some light on that. Any other people and also the opposing party know that the Marcoses ran a dictatorship and hid it under the pretense of democracy. He even enacted martial law and still I heard/and hear people praise him.Is this due to propaganda? Is it fake news? Is this just one side of the story? Many people say that the Aquinos were no different in their corruption. But this documentary does show the facts. Imelda was excessive, the Philippines is an impoverished country, and the citizens are broken.It also hints a stark comparison between the current reigning presidency and America’s current dicta- Ahem AHEM AHEM president. It’s chilling to think that America could one day follow in the dark past of the Philippines. The silver lining was seeing the stories of the survivors. There was a great quote, which I can’t remember of course, but to paraphrase it was something like, the power of democracy elects the president, and revolts ousts them. It shows that you can break the the country and it’s people, but you can not break their spirit. The revolution that ended the regime was a way to move forward. But the fight seems never ending.Alas, as long as there is corruption in government, the power will stay with the rich. I hope this documentary insights people to learn from the past, and learn the importance of reclaiming the reality in truth, and not perception.Oh. Four stars because this should’ve been a mini series.

I'm not super familiar with Laura Greenfield's work, but in my limited knowledge of Generation Wealth and The Queen of Versailles, this is the perfect follow-up to those. I took a course about the history of the Phillippines and while it focused heavily on pre-1900s Phillippines, we, of course, discussed the Marcos regime towards the end of the class. Imelda Marcos is a fascinating character. The Marcos Family itself is just full of heinous characters. Ferdinand Marcos, obviously. But throughout the film, we also learn about Imelda and Bongbong, each awful in their own ways. It's a fascinating look in general at a nation that is going through and has gone through a TON of corruption in its recent history. Imelda is a perfect focus on a documentary like this not just because she is arguably one of the most powerful first ladies in all of the world's modern history, but because she is the perfect snapshot of obscene wealth. Imelda has Monet and Picasso paintings and an obscene amount of shoes and clothes. This all happening in a country that is shown to be going through a significant struggle with many of its citizens facing poverty. What puts this film over the top is that it's well-made. The title, The Kingmaker, refers to Imelda, not just with her husband and how she carried so much power especially socially, but we see her trying to build up her son to become that 'king' of the family in the present day. We also see the Marcos Family trying to make the 'king' of Duterte in order to get Bongbong in power quicker. The aspects of a photography shoot just went on to further highlight Imelda's ridiculous wealth. Perhaps most importantly, though, there is the discussion with opponents of the Marcos power that is able to contradict anything that Imelda may be lying about. This is not a film that glorifies Imelda by any means. It doesn't necessarily deal her a vicious takedown, but rather it gives the audience all the tools we need to make the obvious conclusion that Imelda, despite her sob stories and giving out pity-pay to begging children, is neither a good person, nor worthy of our sympathy.There are tons of incredible and sympathetic characters in this film, though. May Rodriguez's story is truly inspiring. Andy Bautista moving to Oklahoma after investigating Imelda out of fear of Duterte and Marcos is harrowing. The residents of the island that the Marcoses used for their private zoo share their story and it's beyond tragic. The zoo animals are the key metaphor for me. It's the tale of the Marcos Family starting something extremely extravagant, funding it well, then dropping it. Now, the animals just linger there, affected by inbreeding and disease. The ignoring of the animals mirrors the ignoring of the people in the Marcos regime and the refusal to own up and help in any real, tangible, way. Money to beggars on the street will not make up for the years of martial law and tactics used to whitewash history in the favor of Marcos.I think there are some occasions where this feels like it can drag, and by the end of the film it almost feels like an entirely different film than the start. I think that was intentional, but at times it almost seems to lose its own train of thought. I'd have rather had more Imelda stuff mixed in rather then leading with her biography -- but it truly wasn't too affecting to me. This is a well-made biographical documentary that is worth a watch because of how incredible it is.

Con un acceso envidiable a Imelda Marcos, el documental captura la delirante percepción maternal y protectora que ella tiene sobre sí misma, mientras entreteje los crímenes de la dictadura de la que fue cómplice. Un inquietante relato sobre el poder y la memoria, donde la angustia no se construye tanto sobre lo que ya fue, sino por lo que se vislumbra en el futuro político de Filipinas y del mundo.

Inquietante reconstrucción poliédrica del control político que ha ejercido la familia Marcos en Filipinas, comandados por la matriarca Imelda, bajo la supresión, auspicio y financiación de Estados Unidos, así como la supresión de memoria al pueblo.Dominado por entrevistas a cuadro en un montaje que contrasta los testimonios de victimas y victimarios (quienes han encarnado la dictadura), además de material de archivo televisivo y fílmico del mandado de Marcos, Lauren Greenfield presenta dramáticamente la cuasi monárquica estructura "democrática" en este país del sudeste asiático,el cual por cierto, deja de manera apenas visible la participación estadounidense en este conflicto. Uno de lo valores principales del trabajo es que estampa la ola de la derecha regresando al poder, además de los mecanismos y discursos que utilizan para alcanzar su objetivo, lo que (podría) resulta bastante familiar para espectadores del continente americano.Ya lo dijo MC Dinero:"Bla, bla,bla ,blaEl mundo disparaEl mundo consumeLa monarquía es absoluta yaLa monarquía es absoluta yaMi madre disponeMi madre se queja[...]La monarquía me consume[...]LA MONARQUÍA ES ASÍ"

Uffffff, este es un documental de gran presupuesto, y diseñado para ser de alto impacto.Con un tema muy polémico (y que yo ignoraba totalmente), presenta a una mujer que es un personaje creado por ella misma. Muestra su pasado, y nos ayuda a entender su presente. La historia está muy bien contada, y deja ver los actos que rayan en la locura, nacida de la total negación de la realidad. Narra con maestría un buen número de las problemáticas actuales en Filipinas desde el ojo omnipresente y cínico de los Marcos, en especial la matriarca y exprimera dama. A diferencia de The act of killing, Lauren Greenfield no cede uno solo de sus segundos para que el regodeo de sus protagonistas quede impune; los cuestionamientos vienen desde el ángulo con el que la cámara decíde retratarlos.

Buen recorrido por la historia más o menos reciente, con buen rigor periodístico y con buen sumario de talking heads que iban contrastando las declaraciones de Imelda Marcos, la jefa máxima, como titularon en español al documental. Muy bien.

Knowing nothing about history of the Philippines, the Marcos Family or Ferdinand Marcos' time ruling the country, at first this seemed like a documentary about the melancholy Imelda Marcos feels for long lost power and youth. Then you start learning about everything Imelda and her husband did during his presidency (dictatorship, I learned) and how the family is not nearly over with politics.What makes this documentary interesting and good is how it starts with the point of view of Imelda, hence the melancholic tone, and as the director slowly introduces new characters the tone starts to turn into something darker and quite ugly. This keeps the spectator's attention even though it is, in the end, as most expository documentaries, a history lesson.
tangina ng mga m*rcoses

“I don’t have an answer for why we even allow Imelda to open her mouth”The Kingmaker has the potential to be a protest documentary showcasing the Marcos problem before and now. But as the producers are thrown an issue that they can strike and provide a quality documentary exposing the Marcos dirt, they miss and instead give us a mediocre retelling of the dictatorship and a lousy exposition of a rising Marcos-like dictatorship in the county.There’s so much missing from The Kingmaker that irks me, and it’s all because of how reactionary it is.If what the documentary implies is that the Marcoses did so much bad things in the Philippines, then why would the documentary continue to just say “Marcos bad, and marcos continue to be bad”—why not go the extra mile? I was expecting for the documentary to go on a deep dive when they played the Marcos-Dovie Beams sex tape recording, because that recording is very rare. Sadly, the documentary only covers the tip of the iceberg.It also becomes reactionary as the Filipino people also become only extras in this film. Marcoses are the evil ones, Aquinos restored democracy, Duterte is Marcos part II. No, this is not the case and just asserts the status quo of Philippine politics in which someone has to be the face of fascism or the resistance. The film forgets that Marcos had cronies and was backed by the imperialist U.S., the film forgets that the Filipino people and many grassroots activists started the movements against Marcos, the film forgets that the Aquinos also became like Marcos and killed activists and farmers, and the film also skips over the numerous large anti-Marcos burial protests. The film forgets the most essential people: the Filipino people that she oppressed, and the people that ousted her.I know you’re wondering, “This is a documentary about Imelda, why look into a broader perspective?”Because the film implies it. The film implies that the Marcoses did bad things, so why not go deeper and deeper into exposing that. Why not go deeper into the Oplan Tokhang and other human rights violation we continue to face here in the Philippines? This was released in 2019, and there has been so much things skipped over. The documentary tries to be a strong anti-Marcos film, but just becomes a reflection of the political atmosphere of the country: figure-based, glossing over information, and negligent of the actual plight of the masses.MARCOS, DUTERTE, WALANG PINAGIBA! PAREHONG TUTA, DIKTADOR, PASISTA!”
NEVER AGAIN.

Si bien es un documental muy clásico en su forma. La directora, Lauren Greenfield, encuentra en la edición, la fórmula narrativa perfecta para contarnos de manera sumamente detallada y comprensible -contraponiendo los puntos de vista de los actores involucrados-, la distorsionada realidad histórica que Imelda Marcos -primera dama de Filipinas durante 21 años- tiene sobre ella misma y de su papel en la política de Filipinas en la década de los sesentas y hasta la actualidad.Un retrato brutal, cruel, terrorífico y sin juicios de valor, sobre un perfil político popular que hoy en día se está reproduciendo de manera acelerada e inimaginable en todo el mundo.

"The Kingmaker" is woefully short and doesn't really break any new ground when it comes to telling the Marcos story. We've seen and heard this before just with the added "revelation" that Duterte is their proxy candidate — which is kinda obvious already back then even without tin foil hats. If the goal is to make their transgressions known more, I doubt it'll work because you can't convince the pro-Marcos/DDS guys to listen to anything that slights their idols. If you want to "correct" how the youth perceives Martial Law then that's the institutions fault, not a documentary's job. And the voters that matter (the EFG class) likely wouldn't have access to it and probably wouldn't care anyway since the documentary explicitly shows that you can easily subjugate them by doling out cash (and I don't blame them). The middle class already know them and what they did (and mostly loathe them for it), so you're preaching to the choir.What I wanted to see (and disappointingly didn't) was Miriam Santiago since she was part and parcel of that attempt to consolidate the family's power grab and an unapologetic supporter dating back to her days as their speech writer — yet escaped that entire chapter unscathed and with her public image of this revered meritocratic what-if intact. Hell, she's still clawing her way into our social media feeds despite lying six feet under many years later (e.g. alleged clairvoyant of the pandemic with a bill she filed once but never bothered to follow through). You can at least correct the people who believe that.

Defend your right as a citizen of this country.NEVER AGAIN.

"The Kingmaker" is subtle with how it depicts the cunning and devious ways of Imelda Marcos. Actually, it's up to you as the viewer to decide who to side with - Imelda's words or the stories of those who have been oppressed by her family's decisions in the past. Regardless, "The Kingmaker" is a well-balanced documentary that is entertaining as it is cunningly disturbing.It's the 2016 elections and Imelda Marcos is on a mission to make her son Bongbong Marcos the next vice president of the Philippines. Along the way, we get to know the life and the psyche of the woman before she married Ferdinand Marcos, their power during his presidency, and the eventual downfall of their family in 1986 People Power revolution, and their plot to wipe off her family's sinister reputation especially with the younger generation.From its first few minutes, we see Imelda Marcos calm, cool, and collected. Her charm undeniable and even we, as Filipinos, started believing her words. But Lauren Greenfield does amazing work as she subtlety unveils the perceptive reality that Imelda tries to convey against the backdrop of real people who experienced great tragedy through the actions of her and Ferdinand Marcos. The film's tagline uses Imelda's own words that "Perception is real, and the truth is not." is the very real horror in this film. If ever she believes her own lies or lies to the heart to get away with guilt, the truth is that almost everything she started failed to prosper in the long run. It's a reflection of both past wrongs that her family did and the present wrongs that Filipinos are experiencing with its modern politicians. Surprisingly, Lauren Greenfield doesn't force much to assassinate the character of Imelda Marcos as Imelda herself unravels herself. The documentary doesn't really side with any party equally portraying the biases of the other camp. Overall, "The Kingmaker" is a film that every Filipino should watch. It's a warning sign that we really need to remember the sins of the past and that our forgiving nature as a populace is our own undoing in the long run.Source: www.reeladvice.net/2020/05/the-kingmaker-movie-review.html

‘The Kingmaker’ se enfoca en la Primera Dama de Filipinas, Imelda Marcos (a la cual ubicaba siempre de ese excelente disco conceptual de David Byrne y Fatboy Slim). Aquí, la directora Lauren Greenfield nos adentra no sólo a la historia política de su familia (la cual continua hasta la actualidad entre escándalos de corrupción con el actual presidente y la campaña de vicepresidencia de su hijo, Ferdinand), sino con la opulencia de su estilo de vida. Greenfield siempre ha tenido una fascinación por la decadencia de la clase alta y con Marcos ha encontrado un sujeto perfecto. ‘The Kingmaker’ me parece su mejor trabajo, como una crónica plagada de corrupción y despotismo. Este documental formó parte de la selección de Ambulante en casa. Muy recomendable.

Throughout the film there were various commentaries from people and the fact that they weren't positioned in the same background with the exact same static angle was very interesting- each person that gave a commentary gave it in the comfort of either their own home or office with a full frontal view, giving off a feeling of rawness and vulnerability as they spoke, luring the audience to full believe in what they say. In terms of audio, there was one mellow melancholy tune that would play whenever a devastating/unfortunate event was brought up, which would of course elevate the feeling of loss and damage- these two feelings are important because that's the main goal of the documentary: for the people to feel the loss and damage that has happened to the Philippines and the people because of the abuse of power by the Marcos family.Although the film revolved around Imelda, I deeply appreciated how it did not feel biased at all. The people behind the film didn't just interview and capture people in awe of Imelda, but also brought in people who found the family and their doings unjust. You would expect this documentary to be very one-sided, but instead you get two sides battling each other- although it's subtle in the documentary, it's something that is actually happening in real life in the Philippines even up to today.It was clear that Imelda was trying to paint this picture-perfect image of herself to the audience. She repeatedly states that she lost her mother and that she believes she is the mother of the Philippines and that she "birthed" all these great and beautiful things, my only question is: where? Throughout the film I could feel nothing but indecencies coming out of her mouth. I firmly believe in "actions speak louder than words" and there's one scene in the whole documentary that really stood out to me- the scene where Imelda picks up the frame and the other frames fall on the floor. She acts as if nothing happened, she does not even acknowledge, and she goes on and talks about the picture frame she's holding as a worker of her shyly cleans up the broken pieces of glass on the floor. This scene is really interesting as she says all these good things about herself and all yet a small act such as recognizing the frames falling and seeing the worker clean up after her she cannot acknowledge and help. This is very reminiscent of her as a first lady and the Marcos Family- they see what they want and they get it without hesitation, complete unaware of the mess they left behind for the Filipinos to clean up. In addition, throughout the film she mentions that throughout her reign as first lady, she was friends with powerful people all across the globe, further proving how unaware she is of her and herhusband’s doings. She states that she is disgusted with how the government and Philippines is now however she is completely delusional as she doesn’t realize that her and her family has contributed to how the Philippines is no longer “paradise”.Lastly, it’s interesting how this film was made by someone that is not a Filipino. I’m not sure why someone who has no close ties to the Philippines would make a documentary about something so notorious, however, perhaps the fact that it’s so notorious is probably the reason why it was made by the director in the first place. I wondered why no one in the Philippines has made something like this- is it because we are scared of the consequences? Is it because it would be full of bias? Whatever the reason is, I think that the fact this film was made by someone looking at the outside in really gives us a non-biased and equal perspective, as well as a clear division on fact and truth.My gripe with this documentary is how it felt that it shifted to Duterte and that it meandered from Imelda and the main topic on hand, however, I can't really rule this out as the documentary was stating facts and the fact about the Marcos' funding Duterte was vital for people to know.This film was a beautiful yet disturbing layout of Philippine History. Everything was presented in a way that would benefit the feeling and mood of the film. It’s definitely not for people who are very sensitive to the Marcos’ as this film obviously dives deep into them and Imelda’s delusions. Imelda may have thought that this film would bring her and her family justice, however personally, it just justified why the Philippines and its people are having hardships today.Cheers to Lauren Greenfield and her team for doing a fantastic job.

Disclaimer: This is gonna get political due to the fact that I am anti-Marcos and have strong sentiments against dictatorship and media censorship.The Marcos regime has remain to be the most controversial administration in the Philippines. Not only for the numerous allegations and charges that they face, but also for the parade of affluence and wealth of their family. As per the records of anti-corruption agencies, their family has been accused of corruption, violation of human rights, and just recently, perpetration of fake news.Corruption is heavily evident and prevalent in the country. From the local sectors to the national government, it is known to be the root cause of poverty, crime and poor education system. During the Marcos administration, it has been reported that the amount of their so-called ‘ill-gotten wealth’ amount to billions worth of US dollars. In this documentary, they showed some of the acquired properties given to Imelda by his late husband, whom she claimed to be generous for procuring the overseas assets from his hard-earned money. He showered her with innumerable luxurious jewelries and glamorous clothing; All throughout their ruling, Imelda lived like a queen. Hence, the obscene lifestyle and wealth enabled the dictator to extend his presidency and maintain their power that ultimately led to more contentious advances.People power eventually transpired amid chaos fueled by the assassination of Senator Ninoy Aquino; However, it should be noted that it was not the main reason why the resistance emerged. Martial law had been implemented for 8 years – the dark times in Philippine history when human rights and freedom of speech were unheard of - in response to burgeoning hostility that place their throne under threat. Some of the victims, who were mostly activists, spoke of their personal accounts of torture and sexual harassment inflicted onto them by the military/police officials. There were approximately 35,000 Filipinos who went through the same traumatizing experience for speaking out against the misconducts of the government. Opposition groups were silenced, and the media was shutdown. The only voice ever allowed to be heard was from the Conjugal leaders whose reign finally ended after the historic revolution.Until now, the country’s perception of the Marcoses is considerably divided due to the propaganda planted to uphold the legacy of their family name. Despite the charges against them, they still cling onto their false conviction of being trustworthy and country-loving officials as the piles of papers become obsolete edifices. The agencies that are tasked to investigate their family failed to bring them to court and make them admit to their blatant wrongdoings, which is saddening on my end as it’s been ages since the bloody dictatorship took place. Nonetheless, the dark turn of events in the past in relation to the Marcoses’ political careers did not halt the desire to make Malacañang their home once again. In 2016, Bong Bong Marcos, ran for the elections to become Vice President but was greeted by a narrow defeat by Leni Robredo. Since then, he has been attempting to prove that the incumbent VP cheated the elections and thwarted his ascendancy to the position for their contrasting political parties. He had to come up with a plan to gain support from the people and resort to the most accessible propaganda machine: social media. Based on the data gathered from Cambridge Analytica, President Duterte and Bong Bong Marcos are the biggest users of trolls for spreading fake news particularly on Facebook in the Philippines.In my opinion, the administration of Marcos has put the Philippines on the line. Never again to Martial Law. Never again to the dreary cycle of fraudulent conduct, abuse of power, and proliferation of revisionists that are bound to resurface as these unlawful acts are deeply ingrained in their name. Political dynasties ruin the foundation of governance and neglect the needs of the Filipino citizens in favor of their personal interests. Thus, the only way to elude the same fate is to hold the perpetrators accountable and never ever elect them again.

Watched as research for my podcast theatlasbrothers.podbean.com/ for our upcoming episode on The Philippines.The Marcos' reign was clearly a dark period for the nation, although some clearly look back on it with less negativity than others. That's not to say that the country's citizens have been living it up since then - this documentary clearly displays the poverty still experienced by many today.But where Imelda & her family stand out is their mysterious (or maybe not so) riches. And what's worrying about that is the power it gives them to return to politics in The Philippines, whether it's through Bongbong Marcos himself, or through Rodrigo Duterte. More concerning yet is the police brutality the documentary shows has returned in Duterte's presidency. It is sad that the blatant stealing of a nation's wealth has led a family to preventing the social or political evolution of said nation.The documentary itself, is well put-together. Imelda herself is something of a caricature, so I was glad that it took us deeper into the realities of life for Filipinos then and now, rather than just glorifying the greed of her family.

Deft, stylish, sheds light on a (for me) forgotten historical figure. If you check those boxes, I will enjoy your documentary. Imelda is fascinating, Filipino politics are fascinating, lots of uncanny valley parallels to the US political system. Score was bland and almost stock-documentary, with the repetition and the Phillip Glass-isms. Felt like the last third, which was a grand detour into Duterte and contemporary Filipino politics, was a little gratuitous, perhaps trying to rope in Trump-sensitive viewers. But overall, a film I feel much more connected to the world having seen.

We live in a society.Meme aside (which is a valid way of contemporary online discourse), watching this during this time of the independence day of the Philippines. But they are really good at the misinformation part, no thanks partly to Cambridge Analytica and the Zucc. Plus, the undying allegiance of the mayor in chief to not real China. (Taiwan, real China! Free Tibet, TS 1989, etc.) While still living in the worst year ever. Man, Meldy had pushed hard on her supposed motherly approach. That old woman has mommy issues which transformed to rationalizing her hoarding tendencies. I hate living in this neoliberal hellscape but the pandemic really exposed more explicitly to all of us how the system is broken.
Never forget. Never again.

This is a really great documentary. On the surface it is a film about the controversial former first lady of the Philippines Imelda Marcos. In reality, though, this film is about something much deeper, an inside look at the troubling dynastic political landscape of the Southeast Asian country. The Marcos presidency was one marked by scandal, corruption, and crime. The film allows Marcos to provide her version of events, her side of the story, but Lauren Greenfield is too smart a filmmaker to allow Marcos to control the narrative. Greenfield is brilliant in how she sets up her scenes, including moments before and after a given 'take' that showcase and highlight Marcos' narcissism and penchant for self indulgence. Greenfield also provides contrasting points of view, footage that provides context, background, and that conflicts with and juxtaposes the words Imelda Marcos spews. This is a woman whose control and corruption are well known and documented, and Greenfield, a director who makes films about the rich and powerful without glorifying their lifestyles but in fact showcasing everything wrong with them, is the person to tell this story.Eventually the film shifts from being a biodoc on Marcus to the current political landscape in the Philippines, Marcos pushing her son to run for president, and the corrupt state of the Filipino political world and how power is constantly transferred between members of the same few families and how little it has to do with the good of the people, who do not factor in at all with the story, they're not even backdrop for the rich, powerful, and influential, and Greenfield makes this abundantly clear. For the Marcos family, and anyone else running the country, it is all about power, wealth, and notoriety and nothing else. Their aspirations are as vacuous as their sense of taste - they accumulate so much, but ultimately all they have to show for it is a lifetime of horrific behavior, crimes against humanity, and a dark soul and evil heart. Bravo Greenfield! This is how you make a doc about someone and make it mean something!
i cant believe a whole country had to suffer (and continues to suffer) because imelda had mommy issues
Very triggering documentary! - L

“Perception is real. Truth is not.”I wish this was just a harmless portrait of a larger-than-life woman with delusions of grandeur who owned way too many pairs of shoes. Unfortunately, it’s also about how her family, who has stolen billions that the country is still trying to repay, has slowly returned to power. The Kingmaker never clearly states who is telling the truth. It just shows you Imelda Marcos’ account of events during the Marcos dictatorship, then pits that account against what everyone else is saying. The stories of the experiences of Martial Law victims are particularly heartbreaking, but it doesn’t end there. Just as heartbreaking are scenes where current students in a Metro Manila high school are asked about what happened during Martial Law, and their answers range from “our country’s golden age” to “there was peace and order.” And now Imelda is a member of Congress, Imee is a Senator, and Bongbong was a few hundred thousand votes away from being Vice President. The docu is not without its shortcomings, but more people need to see this. Because they need to know. Because we must never forget.PS. We must also never forget that Sandro Marcos shaded two presidents on his ballot in 2016. Thanks for reminding us.

This is a pretty decently made documentary and I will admit that it’s pretty difficult for me a Filipino to be objective about this but I can say with objectivity that this film’s flaw despite its message is that it still gave the Marcos’ a platform and I think we should stop giving monsters a platform to lie straight to you the viewer.Some additional commentsI will say that the film reaches an unbelievable high when it talks to the people but my god there’s just way too much Imelda in this film. A less informed mind might actually think that this movie praises our country’s most famous fascists. I’m so sick and fucking tired of people trying to humanise the Marcos’ which this film does in the first half. I’m just so fucking tired of this bullshit, don’t paint them as anti heroes, don’t put them in front of a camera, just talk to the victims.

An even more dramatic portrait of destructive greed and the consequences of unfettered power and wealth from Lauren Greenfield, the director of “The Queen of Versailles”. Greenfield draws a chilling through line between the history depicted in the doc to politics today in the Philippines (which I won’t spoil).The sheer obliviousness of the main subject, Imelda Marcos provides for some comic relief, but overall it’s a damning study of corruption and an unrepentant would-be Queen.

Documentary filmmaker Lauren Greenfield established with THE QUEEN OF VERSAILLES a talent for digging into and laying bare how the obscenely wealthy will stop at nothing in the pursuit for luxurious, expensive goods that make them feel validated in their gilded bubble of privilege. With THE KINGMAKER, Greenfield extends her fascination with this habitual overindulgence to the realm of politics, where a rich person's gluttonous spending and consuming means that money is being denied to a whole lot of people whose welfare the rich person is ostensibly meant to care for. Former First Lady of the Philippines Imelda Marcos is the focus of Greenfield's probing, involving study of despotic decadence, and when we're given a glimpse of a closet housing Marcos' 1,000+ pairs of nice shoes, it's pretty impossible as an American viewer not to think of how our current President once counted a solid gold toilet as one of his prized possessions.As an interview subject, Marcos is more shrewd at polite evasions and even-tempered rationalizations than Trump ever has been, so Greenfield's interviews with Filipino activists, former political prisoners, and other residents end up being more illuminating than her sit-downs with the woman at the film's center. But while the lack of hugely revealing soundbites from Marcos is a flaw of this solid documentary, it's not one that Greenfield should realistically shoulder the blame for. If non-fiction filmmakers focusing on politics were expected to find and interview only wealth-hoarding rulers who are as rivetingly dumb and vicious as Trump is, it's likely they'd never get any work done.

Lauren Greenfield makes some of the most compelling displays of ego and wealth in documentary cinema. Imelda Marcos is easily the most ambitious target that’s been focused on the opposite end of her camera’s lens. The first couple of minutes, I thought I was essentially watching ‘Queen of Versailles’ again, but set in the Philippines. Especially when we have clips of Marcos handing children dollar bills from the side of her car to the poor citizens of Manilla, and an extended moment of Marcos boast about a photograph in her courtyard while ignoring a bunch of broken picture frames she knocked over getting quietly cleaned up by the Help. But the truth is slowly dripped out, and the film shows a much less “ignorant” and “vain” version of this person, but one that is much more insidious and corrupt.

It's pretty crazy how charisma works on many levels. In The Kingmaker, we see explore this through the Marcos regime and its aftermath (and perhaps future).We see Imelda sitting in her apartment, surrounded by the riches and the beauty she always seems to strive for. Some can probably note the piece behind her as something in the style of Picasso, and yes, it is definitely a Picasso. She even proudly confirms this herself.Imelda has a way with words. She interweaves her personal stories with sentiment, nostalgia, and this whole schtick with maternity (I'll get to that later). It's as sugar-coated as it is convincing, especially if you don't know much about the Marcos family or if your Filipino history game is a bit lacking. Outsiders who are out of the loop may sympathise, and the Filipino viewers -- most of who are tired and weary -- may even be captivated by her through their last shred of hope. But this is where it gets good. I really like how Greenfield lets Imelda talk, then juxtaposes it with accounts from multiple people. The selection was very interesting, with the roster including people who sympathise with -- and fought against --the Marcos regime back in those days. It even includes people who are currently in office (at least during the time of this review). Then suddenly you, the viewer, realise that Imelda's words are like a house of cards. My favourite example of this is Calauit Island, where Greenfield not only tells but shows exactly what exactly it had done to both the animals and people who lived there decades later. This style of show-and-perhaps-contradict repeats throughout the documentary, and Greenfield lets it all speak for itself. You, the viewer, doesn't really have to be told outright that Imelda is a narcissist: it just comes out. She tries to hide it around this whole thing about how she is the, and I loosely quote, "mother of the world". That it perfectly justifies the reason why her son should be in power, and how they were actually doing a good thing (this includes her husband's regime). But through the help of the accounts of others, The Kingmaker paints a disturbingly beautiful picture created by the brushstrokes of horror, pain, and struggle that trickles down even in modern Filipino society. While Imelda sits in places of extravagance, and The Kingmaker, does not hesitate in making us remember where exactly all that money came from. A few notes:- Trigger warning on sexual abuse and torture. I was honestly so mad the whole time May Rodriguez was telling her story. I was so mad for her, and mad that she experienced what she did. Sexual abuse is never okay. - @ the guy who had to pick up those glass shards: I see you, and you are valid.- Does require a basic knowledge of who Marcos is and everything. Since this whole doc is mostly focused on Imelda and their lifestyle, it doesn't delve deep into more of the questionable stuff they've done.- I'd say this doc requires a viewer who is open-minded and can look at things objectively. If you are considering to showing this to your nanay, tatay, and other members of the family, I'd say your chances of making them reconsider their stances are 50/50. I found that it's very easy to attach yourself to Imelda + family and ignore everyone else in this doc, especially if your (insert family member here) has an aversion to Leni Robredo -- who shares a decent amount of screen time in this doc.

I wish the movie had the same ending as Marie Antoinette or maybe Imelda Marcos facing a firing squad. Nonetheless, it’s a powerful documentary that showed me that the Marcos’ greed destroyed the Philippines and they truly may never recover.

The message is clear: your giggling underestimation of her is her greatest gift and deadliest weapon. As abhorrent as she is, it's hard not to be impressed with her dynasty's surprise comeback. It's quite suspicious how this film is framed. From the title itself, it has this desire to say that there's a powerful woman behind every king. It got so tied up to that idea that once they discovered that she's nothing but a depthless, condescending woman, it tried to do damage control by interviewing real victims instead. This came out ingenuine. It wants to be colored using the feministic lens that it failed to deliver that there are also women who cultivate and enable murderers. And, who's to say that the Filipino people are incapable of nurturing tyrannical kings too?The Kingmaker fosters the perception that Imelda protects so much. In her words, "Perception is real, and the truth is not." Her audacity to say that truth is subjective takes me to my wit's end. Plus, the way she keeps talking about the ultimate goal of her life is to birth a country nourished by her "motherly" traits, and, for a while, she's been blessed to be that mother—the Filipino's mother, our mother. If I don't tell you right now ma'am. The only blessing you've received is having a mouth and you've already sinned the moment you opened it. Putangina mo sagad.One thing that I found interesting in this film was the way it illustrated the parallelism of the mini zoo, that the Marcoses have sheltered in Calauit, to the Marcos' clan. Likened to the giraffes and zebras, they're all inbred to create a perilous kingdom—a political dynasty. The one that has been going on for years. They're in a land where they are not welcome, and their inbreeding is almost a tactic to force themselves to remain here—a land that's not theirs to rein. The locals of Calauit gets it. Every day, this mini zoo serves as a reminder that the country is a living circus with power-thirsty freaks. Punyeta hahaI wish the film could have centered more on the victims. They were already there—they interviewed the right people, made them resurface the trauma that stemmed from the injustices during Marcos' regime. It was unfair to give this woman a spotlight. She doesn't deserve to be on-camera at all. We've gone beyond the need for Imelda Marcos to exist. It's time that we burn her along with her 3,000 pair of shoes.
We had to take a break during this because my mom (who left the Philippines to escape martial law) got upset.

Amazing access is given to the former First Lady of the Philippines and we hear in her own words what she believes her legacy to be in her country's history. That the filmmakers essentially have her self-incriminate for some of the worst aspects of her time in power (and make no mistake, she held plenty of power) is revelatory. But it also exposes how much all supposedly democratic nations can colour over their past if a new narrative is more convenient. Scarily relevant for our current political climate.
I'm giving this doc five out of five middle fingers for making me seethe with anger any time a Marcos was on screen to speak."Why do we even let her open her mouth?" INDEED, WHY.

The Kingmaker is a 2019 documentary film written and directed by Lauren Greenfield, featuring the political career of Imelda Marcos with a focus on the Marcos family's efforts to rehabilitate the family's image and to return to political power, including her plans to see her son Bongbong become President of the Philippines, and the alliance that Bongbong and Imee Marcos established with Rodrigo Duterte in his bid to win the 2016 Philippine presidential election.This documentary lays bare the vile nature of the political strategies deployed by the Marcos family. Ferdinand Marcos is deservedly portrayed as a fascist capitalist dictator. But their greed and lust or power does not stop there. After Ferdinand dies and is denied a funeral in the Philippines, they deploy covert secret strategic tactics to regain power, status and regain their former political reign. They abuse social media to spread lies, use smear campaigns to get back their political power, kill power, oust people who intervene in their plans. The list of vile crimes is endless. I was shocked by the fact that the Philippine people still believed in the Marcos family even after Ferdinand Marcos had 30.000 people killed. For some unknown reason they still vote for Imee Marcos, Ferdinand's daughter, and later on even for Bong Bong, Ferdinand's son. Thd most vile betrayal is the political ruse of letting the people believe that Duterte is a better option than Imelda Marcos. In actuality the Marcos family had struck a deal with Duterte, a former minister in Marcos' government, for the mere purpose of letting Duterte become president. Once Duterte becomes president he removes all those who do not agree with Marcos' views. Duterte when inaugurated acts just like his former co-conspirator Ferdinand Marcos. Hence he kills people. and keeps the people in check by oppression. Duterte even abolishes the PCGG, the committee which works towards getting all the money stolen by Marcos. The leader of the PCGG is charged with corruption and fraud. Similar action are taken against the vice president Robredo. At present, Duterte has imprisoned most people who oppose Marcos. Furthermore, Imee has become a senator in the northern region of the Philippines. Duterte, and the Marcos family are now working towards having Bong Bong inaugurated as the new president of the Philippines. So the evil of the Marcos family is about start all over again.

A ridiculously intimate view into the life of Imelda Marcos and the legacy she has left behind. It’s unthinkable how power concentrated in the hands of two people—herself and her husband, back when he was still President—could rip apart the lives of millions, but this documentary leaves no stone unturned in its unflinching exploration of history as shaped by them.The first half of the documentary is laughable, satirical almost, as one listens to Imelda’s own retelling of past events, perfected to a crisp with rehearsed smoothness. But the second half is a punch in the stomach, once Greenfield pieces together various stories regarding the political scene in the Philippines to flesh out a portrait of greed, corruption, lavishness and cruelty that now runs through generations. Not only do the effects of the Marcos regime still reverberate deeply through the country today, it feels almost as if they have never left with their relentless quest to return to power. The photography is straightforward but agile; the editing simple but powerful; the soundtrack eerie but compelling. Put together, there cannot be a title more aptly descriptive about the rise (and fall and rise again) of Imelda than “The Kingmaker”.

Imelda Marcos should be rotting in jail at this point, and yet she lives like a queen. In America, the male equivalent to Imelda reigns, and everything he touches turns to death, all the while enriching his family.

An object lesson in a documentarian's restraint, as Imelda Marcos displays all of the messianic pretensions that were the hallmark of the dictatorial regime she was at the head of and seeks to perpetuate through her children, who still hold sway despite their legacy of vast corruption and thousands of extrajudicial killings during the eight years of Ferdinand Marcos' martial law decree. Lauren Greenfield's documentary might well be the defining record of the end of three decades of Philippine democracy and the return to ruthless, kleptocratic autocracy.
If you're looking for another populist dictator's rise to power to be terrified of, this is a must watch! Boy oh boy does democracy burn so easy!

The Kingmaker is a masterpiece of documentary filmmaking. With clever editing, unexpectedly candid interviews and a recurring visual metaphor that keeps on giving, it is an impeccable depiction of how kleptocracy, ahistoricity and dynastic politics lead to Fascism. Its themes are applicable way beyond the Philippines but as a primer to the country's politics it is incredibly smooth.

NZIFF 2020 #15So incredibly interesting. I've read a lot about the Philippines politics from the last 4 years, but prior to that I knew nothing so 'The kingmaker' was super informative. The way the film is set out, really gave this story the best emotional impact possible. It did leave the moral question though, even if someone like Imelda Marcos comes off looking evil, is it right to give her a platform like this in the first place? even for international audiences, it’s still questionable that this woman be given a platform to speak (no matter how tongue-in-cheek its presentation aims to be). we don’t need to hear the marcoses speak to see what they’ve done to the philippines. this documentary meanders its way to its “shocking” conclusion, taking its time to first portray imelda as an eccentric, delusional, and seemingly harmless old bat. but we shouldn’t have to hear what the marcoses have to say anymore, no matter how ridiculous

The Kingmaker is an eye-opener.This documentary film taught me more about the true history of my country than what I merely heard growing up.Regardless of one's political views, everyone needs to watch this because it's dangerous to live believing that "Perception is real, and the truth is not."The past is not forgotten.

In this day and age where corruption is widespread in my own land, it is most disheartening to see these political families achieve the full potential of their own charisma towards the blind masses. Backstabbing is irrelevant in my country as these politicians outrightly plunder from their own people. Filipinos are groaning and moaning since the Spanish rule, but to have this injustice come from your own countrymen is truly disgusting.Although unique from each other, the message is the same with the strong contemporary documentaries released within the first years of President Duterte’s administration such as A Thousand Cuts and Aswang. Compared with the two however, Lauren Greenfield’s film is more well-edited, hinting parallelisms from the past Marcos administration with the current government, making Imelda Marcos as the bridge that kept filling the gap between the two. Grandiose and almost royal in manner, I see Imelda in a two-headed monster having one neck that is filled of delusions of grandeur. The monster’s other head died, and as the head was cut off and laid unfortunately to rest amongst the honorables, one head continues to rise. And with these heads, a neck kept on and keeps on turning these heads to serve their own selfish purpose. This ardent and repugnantly wide neck is Imelda herself. Being true to her brand, Imelda blatantly shows wealth, which is a manifestation of her own understanding of beauty and love. But hidden beneath her clamor were the suffering of many Filipinos: from the residents of Calauit island to the murder and rape victims of Martial Law and to all the Filipinos, to whom the Marcoses are still accountable for. She stood by Ferdinand Marcos dictatorial rule and she’s standing by Bongbong’s political route to power. The rise and fall and their rising again feels like that Filipinos are inside a horror movie wherein it doesn’t matter how many times you kill the monster. Rest assured that after the end credits, a resurrection will be shown, which will birth a series of never-ending sequels. A truly scary state for an already aching country, a disease-stricken country.With our body there are lots of checks and balances that maintain homeostasis. Likened to a well-oiled machine, it is very organized up to a certain point wherein a harmful external factor can damage the whole organism. With my country, it seems that there’s a gradual reversal of this homeostasis. Slowly creeping in in the very own checks and balances of this country’s institutions. And without recognition from its own members, it will persist, continually making the whole country sick and killing its people one by one until there are no more Filipinos worth dying for.As a healer by profession, I tend to the sick. And whenever I encounter patients who I know have a lower chance of survival, wherein limitations of science and the practice of medicine are fully exhausted, it eats me to the core. There is so much that I can do to save a life, but one can’t save them all. The same feeling of hopelessness is what I feel with my country. A dim reflection I know, but by not stating this singular groan from a citizen, societal problems will not be recognized. And with this film it serves this purpose: recalling the past, stating the present and heeding a warning for the future.

A very fascinating snapshot into the history of Filipino politics and the Marcos’ (nasty) dynasty. I’ve heard about Imelda’s crazy excessive extravagant lifestyle, but didn’t realize it was more than just that. As an outsider, I can’t help but feel sad for Filipinos whose lives could have been so much better if not for the corrupt Marcos government.

"If these people [the Marcoses] will be brought to power again, there's a very big chance that the sins of the past will be committed again in the future."The Kingmaker managed to acclimate the political situation here in the Philippines, both then and now. When I was 8 years old, I remember my father brought a CD of Imelda (2003) when he came home from work in Manila. I had a vague memory of me watching this film on TV, together with my family, when Netflix or any streaming services weren't concepted yet. Little did I know that beyond the tapestry of all Imelda's extravagant furniture and her infamous 3,000 pair of shoe collection shown in the film, is a lady who stood by a tyrant and a dictator, who's ill-gotten wealth is being paid off by the Filipino people up to this very moment.What's even more baffling is the fact that in The Kingmaker, Imelda claims that the era of Martial Law in the Philippines upheld "sovereignty, freedom, justice, and human rights" in our country. Excuse me, Ma'am? Last time I checked, the Martial Law era perpetuated exactly the opposites of what you claimed--it was the darkest and most brutal time in the Philippines. Journalists were executed, activists were tortured and arrested, and newspaper outlets were silenced. I am outraged. It saddens me how students here define Marcos' era as being peaceful and disciplined, as per reflected in the documentary. It's as though all extrajudicial killings, arrests, and tortures never even took place. I really hope colleges would mandatorily employ Martial law studies in order to revisit the past, and scrutinize where things have gone wrong. I'm glad how this documentary also pointed out the current Duterte Administration. Vis-a-vis Marcos' era as a point of reference, I could enunciate a number of similarities between their presidencies. It's like reliving the past and the horrors all over again. God bless the Philippines. Catch me on the road to Mars whenever time permits so. #NeverForget#MarcosNotAHero

“I was always criticized for being excessive, but that is the spirit of mothering! You cannot quantify love!”This film does an excellent job capturing Imelda Marcos as both a charismatic, captivating force of nature (still! at ninety!) AND as a batshit crazy tyrant. Greenfield’s interviews with the controversial dictatorial matriarch provide shocking, probably unparalleled access into the views of a woman reflecting with pride upon half a century of corruption. For me, the most insane new understanding gleaned from Marcos’ life-story is that while we like to simplify “evil” as the act of doing wrong for the sake of self-interest, Marcos truly seems to believe that her greed and self-martyrdom and megalomania and family dynasty building is good for the Philippines and the world. And that upside-down vision of morality is far scarier than a complete lack of it. At one point in the film, Marcos declares: “perception is real, and the truth is not.” That belief is likely the single greatest threat to humanity. Holy fuck.
"Perception is real and the truth is not"Imelda's "when you lose your money (mother).." Freudian slip is the best one I've ever heard.

Imelda Marcos is just spouting lies here, and I can’t even imagine bearing to watch it. Flaunting her fashion, wealth, life, and motherhood makes me so goddamn angry and cringe at the same time. I just can’t believe she has this platform to talk about her nonsense.I appreciate how Lauren Greenfield, a foreigner, has been so eager to share this story so the wider world can learn about the past horrors in the Philippines under the Marcos regime, which are repeating themselves under the Duterte administration. However, this film felt neutral and detached from the harsh reality faced by the victims of the Marcos regime. Maybe it’s because it’s coming from a filmmaker who didn’t experience martial law firsthand and grew up far from the story, relying only on research.It remains too safe, and the juxtaposition of ideas doesn’t really work for this kind of topic. People in the Philippines who experienced martial law and those who grew up hearing the horrifying stories and studying the history—we know that Ferdinand Marcos is no hero, and we will never forget his evil deeds. There is only one side to the story about the Marcoses: they are monsters. It scares me that this documentary might confuse people who aren’t familiar with the Marcos regime, and worst of all, they might feel sympathy for the Marcos family.
